Open table in a new tab The Gram-negative (ecFabI) and Gram-positive (saFabI) enoyl-ACP reductases have many properties in common, but are distinguished by their cofactor selectivities. The cofactor specificity of ecFabI has been the subject of some debate. The initial report of enoyl-ACP reductase activity in cell extracts suggested that two enzymes were present in E. coli, one requiring NADH and the other utilizing NADPH (29.Weeks G. Wakil S.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1968; 243: 1180-1189Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The pH optima of the two enzymes were slightly different, with the NADH activity being maximal at pH 7.5 and the NADPH activity preferring pH 6.5. Subsequent genetic and biochemical experiments lead to the conclusion that there is only a single NADH-dependent enoyl-ACP reductase gene in E. coli (3.Heath R.J. Rock C.O. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 26538-26542Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (318) Google Scholar, 30.Bergler H. Wallner P. Ebeling A. Leitinger B. Fuchsbichler S. Aschauer H. Kollenz G. Högenauer G. Turnowsky F. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 5493-5496Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). However, Bergler et al. (31.Bergler H. Fuchsbichler S. Högenauer G. Turnowsky F. Eur. J. Biochem. 1996; 242: 689-694Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar) recently reported that ecFabI has both NADH- and NADPH-dependent activities. The NADPH-dependent activity was only revealed when ecFabI was purified at acidic pH, and this activity was irreversibly lost when the pH was raised to 7.0 or above (31.Bergler H. Fuchsbichler S. Högenauer G. Turnowsky F. Eur. J. Biochem. 1996; 242: 689-694Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar). We have attempted to exactly repeat these experiments without success, and conclude from our present study that ecFabI is highly selective for NADH. In contrast, saFabI is clearly a NADPH-dependent reductase that exhibits a high degree of positive cooperativity. This property cannot be considered characteristic of Gram-positive FabI enzymes because the enoyl-ACP reductase from Bacillus subtilis is a NADH-dependent enzyme.2Otherwise, saFabI has specific activities that are very similar to ecFabI for synthetic substrates and is able to complement E. coli strains that are defective in ecFabI. S. aureusproduces branched-chain fatty acids (32.White D.C. Frerman F.E. J. Bacteriol. 1968; 95: 2198-2209Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), and its ability to substitute for ecFabI in an organism that produces straight-chain saturated and unsaturated fatty acids illustrates the broad substrate specificity of enoyl-ACP reductases. The structural similarities between triclosan and hexachlorophene suggest that they have a common target, and both drugs inhibit enoyl-ACP reductases in vitro. The resistance of FabI(G93V) to both triclosan and hexachlorophene support the concept that both drugs interact with FabI in the vicinity of the substrate binding site. However, the resistance of E. coli to hexachlorophene and the genetic analysis of S. aureus argues that FabI is not a biologically relevant target for the cellular action of hexachlorophene. The ability of FabI inhibitors to form stable ternary complexes with the enzyme is the critical feature required for antibacterial activity (Fig. 8). This class of agents are called slow-binding inhibitors because inhibitor complexes with the enzyme take a long time (seconds to minutes) to form relative to the catalytic rate (28.Morrison J.F. Walsh C.T. Adv. Enzymol. 1988; 61: 201-301PubMed Google Scholar). This is due to a slow conformational isomerization of the enzyme-drug complex from a state where the enzyme and drug are in rapid equilibrium to a state where the enzyme-drug complex undergoes very slow dissociation (Fig. 8). Triclosan exhibits all the hallmarks of a classic slow-binding inhibitor. The inhibition of FabI by triclosan becomes progressively stronger with time and is essentially irreversible after several minutes (12.Heath R.J. Rubin J.R. Holland D.R. Zhang E. Snow M.E. Rock C.O. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 11110-11114Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (431) Google Scholar). This irreversible inhibition correlates with the formation of a stable FabI-NAD+-triclosan ternary complex (12.Heath R.J. Rubin J.R. Holland D.R. Zhang E. Snow M.E. Rock C.O. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 11110-11114Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (431) Google Scholar, 13.Levy C.W. Roujeinikova A. Sedelnikova S. Baker P.J. Stuitje A.R. Slabas A.R. Rice D.W. Rafferty J.B. Nature. 1999; 398: 383-384Crossref PubMed Scopus (433) Google Scholar) that is accompanied by a conformational change in a flexible loop in FabI including residues 194 to 210 (14.Stewart M.J. Parikh S. Xiao G. Tonge P.J. Kisker C. J. Mol. Biol. 1999; 290: 859-865Crossref PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar). The diazaborines are another class of potent FabI inhibitors that act via the formation of a tight binding bisubstrate complex (6.Baldock C. de Boer G.-J. Rafferty J.B. Stuitje A.R. Rice D.W. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1998; 55: 1541-1549Crossref PubMed Scopus (75) Google Scholar). The formation of the FabI-NAD+-diazaborine inhibitory complex is also accompanied by an analogous conformational change in this flexible loop (5.Baldock C. Rafferty J.B. Sedelnikova S.E. Baker P.J. Stuitje A.R. Slabas A.R. Hawkes T.R. Rice D.W. Science. 1996; 274: 2107-2110Crossref PubMed Scopus (215) Google Scholar). In contrast, hexachlorophene neither exhibits the kinetic properties of a slow-binding inhibitor nor forms a ternary complex. Our results point to the ether linkage in triclosan as a structural feature that is essential to the formation of the inhibitory ternary complex. This conclusion is drawn from the fact that dihydroxydiphenylether is a FabI inhibitor, whereas dihydroxydiphenylmethane is not. Triclosan is sandwiched between the protein and the cofactor and a hydrogen bond network and stacking interactions form the bridge that connects the drug, protein and NAD+ (12.Heath R.J. Rubin J.R. Holland D.R. Zhang E. Snow M.E. Rock C.O. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 11110-11114Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (431) Google Scholar, 13.Levy C.W. Roujeinikova A. Sedelnikova S. Baker P.J. Stuitje A.R. Slabas A.R. Rice D.W. Rafferty J.B. Nature. 1999; 398: 383-384Crossref PubMed Scopus (433) Google Scholar, 14.Stewart M.J. Parikh S. Xiao G. Tonge P.J. Kisker C. J. Mol. Biol. 1999; 290: 859-865Crossref PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar). Clearly, the substitution of a carbon bridge in hexachlorophene for the ether oxygen in triclosan results in a compound that cannot orient itself to optimally participate in this network. This is most likely attributed to the different angle of the carbon bridge compared with the ether bridge, preventing hexachlorophene from forming hydrogen bond connections and the stacking interactions with NAD+. Stewart et al. (14.Stewart M.J. Parikh S. Xiao G. Tonge P.J. Kisker C. J. Mol. Biol. 1999; 290: 859-865Crossref PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar) propose that the ether oxygen of triclosan is part of a hydrogen bond network that also includes the hydroxyl groups of Tyr-156, triclosan, and the NAD+ ribose (14.Stewart M.J. Parikh S. Xiao G. Tonge P.J. Kisker C. J. Mol. Biol. 1999; 290: 859-865Crossref PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar). However, the distance between these atoms is about 4 Å in the various published structures (12.Heath R.J. Rubin J.R. Holland D.R. Zhang E. Snow M.E. Rock C.O. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 11110-11114Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (431) Google Scholar, 13.Levy C.W. Roujeinikova A. Sedelnikova S. Baker P.J. Stuitje A.R. Slabas A.R. Rice D.W. Rafferty J.B. Nature. 1999; 398: 383-384Crossref PubMed Scopus (433) Google Scholar, 14.Stewart M.J. Parikh S. Xiao G. Tonge P.J. Kisker C. J. Mol. Biol. 1999; 290: 859-865Crossref PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar), and it seems unlikely that this weak hydrogen bond acceptor will significantly contribute to the binding affinity at that distance. The substitution of a thioether for the ether in hydroxydiphenyl compounds also significantly reduces antibacterial activity (10.Heath R.J., Yu, Y.-T. Shapiro M.A. Olson E. Rock C.O. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 30316-30321Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (323) Google Scholar), indicating that the bulkier sulfur atom also prevents the proper alignment of the aromatic rings and hydroxyl group in the FabI active site. Thus, the presence of the ether oxygen is clearly important in promoting tight drug binding and the ensuing conformational change that leads to essentially irreversible FabI inhibition and potent antibacterial activity. We thank Amy Sullivan and Magda Kaminska for their excellent technical assistance, Charles Ross for molecular modeling, Rocco Gogliotti and John Domagala for the substrate analogs, Martin Shapiro for the MIC determinations, and Eric Olson for evaluation of the manuscript.

Based on homology with GLUT1-5, we have isolated a cDNA for a novel glucose transporter, GLUTX1. This cDNA encodes a protein of 478 amino acids that shows between 29 and 32% identity with rat GLUT1-5 and 32-36% identity with plant and bacterial hexose transporters. Unlike GLUT1-5, GLUTX1 has a short extracellular loop between transmembrane domain (TM) 1 and TM2 and a long extracellular loop between TM9 and TM10 that contains the only N-glycosylation site. When expressed in Xenopus oocytes, GLUTX1 showed strong transport activity only after suppression of a dileucine internalization motif present in the amino-terminal region. Transport activity was inhibited by cytochalasin B and partly competed by D-fructose and D-galactose. The Michaelis-Menten constant for glucose was approximately 2 mM. When translated in reticulocytes lysates, GLUTX1 migrates as a 35-kDa protein that becomes glycosylated in the presence of microsomal membranes. Western blot analysis of GLUTX1 transiently expressed in HEK293T cells revealed a diffuse band with a molecular mass of 37-50 kDa that could be converted to a approximately 35-kDa polypeptide following enzymatic deglycosylation. Immunofluorescence microscopy detection of GLUTX1 transfected into HEK293T cells showed an intracellular staining. Mutation of the dileucine internalization motif induced expression of GLUTX1 at the cell surface. GLUTX1 mRNA was detected in testis, hypothalamus, cerebellum, brainstem, hippocampus, and adrenal gland. We hypothesize that, in a similar fashion to GLUT4, in vivo cell surface expression of GLUTX1 may be inducible by a hormonal or other stimulus.

Activation of phosphoinositide 3-kinases is coupled to both phosphotyrosine/growth factor and G protein-coupled receptors. We explored the role of phosphoinositide 3-kinase activation in myocardium during in vivo pressure overload hypertrophy in mice. Cytosolic extracts from wild type hypertrophied hearts showed a selective increase in the phosphoinositide 3-kinase γ isoform. To address the role of G protein-coupled receptor-mediated activation of phosphoinositide 3-kinase, we used transgenic mice with cardiac-specific overexpression of a Gβγ sequestering peptide. Extracts from hypertrophied transgenic hearts showed complete loss of phosphoinositide 3-kinase activation, indicating a Gβγ-dependent process. To determine the class of G proteins that contribute Gβγ dimers for in vivophosphoinositide 3-kinase activation, two strategies were used: 1) transgenic mice with cardiac-specific overexpression of a Gq inhibitor peptide and 2) pertussis toxin treatment prior to pressure overload in wild type mice. Pressure overloaded Gq inhibitor transgenic mice showed a complete absence of phosphoinositide 3-kinase activation, whereas pretreatment with pertussis toxin showed robust phosphoinositide 3-kinase activation. Taken together, these data demonstrate that activation of the phosphoinositide 3-kinase during in vivo pressure overload hypertrophy is Gβγ-dependent and the Gβγ dimers arise from stimulation of Gq-coupled receptors. Given the importance of phosphoinositides in cellular function and the link between PI3K, heterotrimeric G proteins, and mitogen-activated protein kinase pathways, we sought to determine whether PI3K is activated during in vivo cardiac pressure overload. Considering its widening role as an important signaling molecule, we sought to determine whether activity of PI3K was altered in in vivo cardiac hypertrophy. The data presented in this study provide evidence for isoform specific regulation of PI3K during the cardiac hypertrophic process. Sci. 1997; 22: 355-358Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (644) Google Scholar) makes the activation of this signaling pathway in hypertrophy quite interesting, especially when considering that chronic pressure overload can lead to a transition from compensatory hypertrophy to decompensated heart failure.Our study was directed to address the mechanism of PI3K activation during in vivo cardiac hypertrophy. Interestingly, we show a significant activation of PI3Kγ but not PI3Kα. The activation of the γ isoform implicates G protein-coupled receptor-mediated activation of PI3K during this hypertrophic process with little induction from phospho-tyrosine/growth factor receptors. We sought to establish this observation in the in vivo context of pressure overload hypertrophy. Using transgenic mice with cardiac-specific overexpression of the Gβγ binding domain of βARK1, Gβγ subunits would be sequestered blocking Gβγ-dependent signaling (18.Koch W.J. Rockman H.A. Samama P. Hamilton R.A. Bond R.A. Milano C.A. Lefkowitz R.J. Science. 1995; 268: 1350-1353Crossref PubMed Scopus (635) Google Scholar). Despite the marked induction of cardiac hypertrophy in hearts from TAC transgenic βARKct mice, no increase in lipid kinase activity was found demonstrating that the induction of PI3K activity is Gβγ-mediated involving the p110γ isoform.Having documented that activation of PI3K in vivo is Gβγ-dependent, we sought to determine the specific class of heterotrimeric G proteins that contributes the Gβγ subunits. In vitro studies have shown the activation of PI3K to be mediated through Gi class of G proteins (32.Gutkind J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 1839-1842Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (689) Google Scholar). To address this issue in the in vivo context, we used transgenic mice with cardiac-specific overexpression of a peptide that blocks dissociation of the heterotrimeric Gq class of G proteins. If the signal was mediated through the Gi class of G proteins, then TAC in GqI transgenic animals would show significant activation of PI3K since Gi-mediated signaling is intact in these animals (3.Akhter S.A. Luttrell L.M. Rockman H.A. Iaccarino G. Lefkowitz R.J. Koch W.J. Science. 1998; 280: 574-577Crossref PubMed Scopus (393) Google Scholar). Interestingly, we show that the increase in PI3K activity in hypertrophied hearts was abolished in the transgenic GqI mice, suggesting that the Gβγ subunits needed to activate PI3K are derived from Gq. To address this issue using a different strategy, we administered PTX after TAC to abolish Gi-mediated signaling. Our data show that activation of PI3K was unaffected by PTX treatment indicating the signaling pathway to be independent of the Gi-coupled receptor stimulation during in vivo pressure overload. Considering the complex pathophysiological state of the heart during pressure overload hypertrophy, it is remarkable that induction of PI3K appears to be mediated by activation of Gq-coupled G proteins. Further studies will be needed to determine whether PI3K is an upstream molecule in regulation of SAPKs during the hypertrophic process.Since PKB is a known downstream target of PI3K, we wanted to test whether the activation of PKB in vivo is regulated by PI3K. Our data from wild type TAC hearts show a significant increase in PKB activity that is abolished in pressure overloaded transgenic mice with cardiac-specific overexpression of either the βARKct or GqI peptides. These data show that, in the pressure overloaded heart, PKB is regulated by similar signals that regulate PI3K. Although activation of PI3K does not appear to be required for the induction of cardiac hypertrophy, we can only speculate as to what role PI3K activation may play during this process. It is interesting to note that induction of PI3K activates anti-apoptotic signaling (17.Marte B.M. Downward J. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1997; 22: 355-358Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (644) Google Scholar), and activation of PI3K could serve to counterbalance pro-apoptotic pathways during compensatory hypertrophy. In this regard, recent studies have documented the induction of pro-apoptotic pathways in pathological cardiac hypertrophy (33.Hirota H. Chen J. Betz U.A. Rajewsky K. Gu Y. Ross Jr., J. Muller W. Class II PI3K has substrate specificity for PtdIns and phosphatidylinositol-4-phosphate (PtdIns(4)P); however, the role of this kinase with respect to in vivo signaling pathways is not well understood (10.Brown R.A. Domin J. Arcaro A. Waterfield M.D. Shepherd P.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 14529-14532Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (118) Google Scholar). The class I PI3Ks are the best characterized and most intensely studied. Class I PI3Ks use PtdIns, PtdIns(4)P, and PtdIns(4,5)P2 as substrates leading to the formation of PtdIns(3)P, PtdIns (3,4)P2, and PtdIns(3,4,5)P3, respectively, which all could act as potential secondary messengers (11.Toker A. Cantley L.C. Nature. 1997; 387: 673-676Crossref PubMed Scopus (1218) Google Scholar). Class I P13Ks are all heterodimers containing a regulatory subunit (p85, p55/50, p101) and the 110-kDa catalytic subunit (7.Rameh L.E. Cantley L.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 8347-8350Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (848) Google Scholar, 12.Stephens L.R. Eguinoa A. Erdjument-Bromage H. Lui M. Cooke F. Coadwell J. Smrcka A.S. Thelen M. Cadwallader K. Tempst P. Hawkins P.T. Cell. 1997; 89: 105-114Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (491) Google Scholar). To date four isoforms of the p110 catalytic subunit have been characterized (α, β, γ, and δ), and all contain a carboxyl-terminal lipid kinase domain in addition to a Ras-binding site and PI3K protein kinase activity. Catalytic subunits of the class I PI3Ks are further subdivided into two subclasses (A and B) depending on the type of regulatory unit with which they associate. Class IA PI3K catalytic subunits include p110α, -β, and -δ and interact with the p85 adapter regulatory unit to form heterodimers (13.Hiles I.D. Otsu M. Volinia S. Fry M.J. Gout I. Dhand R. Panayotou G. Ruiz-Larrea F. Thompson A. Totty N.F. Hsuan J. Courtneidge S.A. Parker P.J. Waterfield M.D. Cell. 1992; 70: 419-429Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (540) Google Scholar). The p85 adapters contain Src homology 2 domains, thereby linking class IA catalytic subunits to protein-tyrosine kinase signaling pathways. In contrast, the class IB PI3K p110γ catalytic subunit is directly activated by βγ-subunits of heterotrimeric G proteins (14.Stoyanov B. Volinia S. Hanck T. Rubio I. Loubtchenkov M. Malek D. Stoyanova S. Vanhaesebroeck B. Dhand R. Nurnberg B. Gierschik P. Seedorf K. Hsuan J.J. Waterfield M.D. Wetzker R. Science. 1995; 269: 690-693Crossref PubMed Scopus (639) Google Scholar). Tight association with the p101 regulatory adapter allows translocation of p110γ to the nucleus (15.Metjian A. Roll R.L. Ma A.D. Abrams C.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 27943-27947Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar). Thus, through activation of p110γ, stimulation of a variety of G protein-coupled receptors can increase the level of 3′-phosphorylated PtdIns, which in turn act as potent signaling molecules (7.Rameh L.E. Cantley L.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 8347-8350Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (848) Google Scholar). In this regard, a number of downstream signaling molecules have been shown to interact with phosphoinositides resulting in their membrane targeting and/or in modulation of their enzyme activity (7.Rameh L.E. Cantley L.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 8347-8350Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (848) Google Scholar). Examples include activation of the GTP-binding protein Rac, (16.Missy K. Van Poucke V. Raynal P. Viala C. Mauco G. Plantavid M. Chap H. Payrastre B. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 30279-30286Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar), the non-classical protein kinase C isoforms (δ, ε, τ, and ζ) (11.Toker A. Cantley L.C. Nature. 1997; 387: 673-676Crossref PubMed Scopus (1218) Google Scholar), and proteins containing a pleckstrin homology domain, such as protein kinase B (PKB)/v-Akt (11.Toker A. Cantley L.C. Nature. 1997; 387: 673-676Crossref PubMed Scopus (1218) Google Scholar). The pleckstrin homology domain containing protein PKB/v-Akt, is of interest because of its role in activation of cell survival signals (17.Marte B.M. Downward J. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1997; 22: 355-358Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (644) Google Scholar). Furthermore, recent evidence has linked PI3K to activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase pathways (5.Lopez-Ilasaca M. Crespo P. Pellici P.G. Gutkind J.S. Wetzker R. Science. 1997; 275: 394-397Crossref PubMed Scopus (627) Google Scholar), making it a potential intermediate enzyme in the development of cardiac hypertrophy. To date little is known about PI3K signaling in heart. Given the importance of phosphoinositides in cellular function and the link between PI3K, heterotrimeric G proteins, and mitogen-activated protein kinase pathways, we sought to determine whether PI3K is activated during in vivo cardiac pressure overload. We further wanted to determine the mechanism for PI3K activation in cardiac hypertrophy. DISCUSSIONRecent studies have implicated PI3K in a wide array of cellular processes such as intracellular trafficking (24.Stack J.H. Horazdovsky B. Emr S.D. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Biol. 1995; 11: 1-33Crossref PubMed Scopus (172) Google Scholar), actin cytoskeleton regulation (17.Marte B.M. Downward J. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1997; 22: 355-358Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (644) Google Scholar), insulin signaling (25.Cross D.A. Alessi D.R. Cohen P. Andjelkovich M. Hemmings B.A. Nature. 1995; 378: 785-789Crossref PubMed Scopus (4326) Google Scholar), and inhibition of apoptotic signals (17.Marte B.M. Downward J. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1997; 22: 355-358Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (644) Google Scholar). Considering its widening role as an important signaling molecule, we sought to determine whether activity of PI3K was altered in in vivo cardiac hypertrophy. The data presented in this study provide evidence for isoform specific regulation of PI3K during the cardiac hypertrophic process. Furthermore, we demonstrate that activation of PI3K is Gβγ-dependent and, moreover, the specific Gβγ subunits responsible are derived from the Gq class of heterotrimeric G proteins.Regulation of hypertrophic growth is by the induction of a number of key signaling cascades involving G protein-coupled receptors, mitogen-activated protein kinases, receptor tyrosine kinase, and janus kinase/signal tranducers and activators of transcription pathways (26.Force T. We sought to establish this observation in the in vivo context of pressure overload hypertrophy. Using transgenic mice with cardiac-specific overexpression of the Gβγ binding domain of βARK1, Gβγ subunits would be sequestered blocking Gβγ-dependent signaling (18.Koch W.J. Rockman H.A. Samama P. Hamilton R.A. Bond R.A. Milano C.A. Lefkowitz R.J. Science. 1995; 268: 1350-1353Crossref PubMed Scopus (635) Google Scholar). Despite the marked induction of cardiac hypertrophy in hearts from TAC transgenic βARKct mice, no increase in lipid kinase activity was found demonstrating that the induction of PI3K activity is Gβγ-mediated involving the p110γ isoform.Having documented that activation of PI3K in vivo is Gβγ-dependent, we sought to determine the specific class of heterotrimeric G proteins that contributes the Gβγ subunits. In vitro studies have shown the activation of PI3K to be mediated through Gi class of G proteins (32.Gutkind J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 1839-1842Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (689) Google Scholar). To address this issue in the in vivo context, we used transgenic mice with cardiac-specific overexpression of a peptide that blocks dissociation of the heterotrimeric Gq class of G proteins. If the signal was mediated through the Gi class of G proteins, then TAC in GqI transgenic animals would show significant activation of PI3K since Gi-mediated signaling is intact in these animals (3.Akhter S.A. Luttrell L.M. Rockman H.A. Iaccarino G. Lefkowitz R.J. Koch W.J. Science. 1998; 280: 574-577Crossref PubMed Scopus (393) Google Scholar). Interestingly, we show that the increase in PI3K activity in hypertrophied hearts was abolished in the transgenic GqI mice, suggesting that the Gβγ subunits needed to activate PI3K are derived from Gq. To address this issue using a different strategy, we administered PTX after TAC to abolish Gi-mediated signaling. Our data show that activation of PI3K was unaffected by PTX treatment indicating the signaling pathway to be independent of the Gi-coupled receptor stimulation during in vivo pressure overload. Considering the complex pathophysiological state of the heart during pressure overload hypertrophy, it is remarkable that induction of PI3K appears to be mediated by activation of Gq-coupled G proteins. Further studies will be needed to determine whether PI3K is an upstream molecule in regulation of SAPKs during the hypertrophic process.Since PKB is a known downstream target of PI3K, we wanted to test whether the activation of PKB in vivo is regulated by PI3K. Our data from wild type TAC hearts show a significant increase in PKB activity that is abolished in pressure overloaded transgenic mice with cardiac-specific overexpression of either the βARKct or GqI peptides. These data show that, in the pressure overloaded heart, PKB is regulated by similar signals that regulate PI3K. Although activation of PI3K does not appear to be required for the induction of cardiac hypertrophy, we can only speculate as to what role PI3K activation may play during this process. It is interesting to note that induction of PI3K activates anti-apoptotic signaling (17.Marte B.M. Downward J. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1997; 22: 355-358Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (644) Google Scholar), and activation of PI3K could serve to counterbalance pro-apoptotic pathways during compensatory hypertrophy. Hypoxia-inducible factor 1α (HIF-1α) and the HIF-like factor (HLF) are two highly related basic Helix-Loop-Helix/Per-Arnt-Sim (bHLH/PAS) homology transcription factors that undergo dramatically increased function at low oxygen levels. Despite strong similarities in their activation mechanisms (e.g. they both undergo rapid hypoxia-induced protein stabilization, bind identical target DNA sequences, and induce synthetic reporter genes to similar degrees), they are both essential for embryo survival via distinct functions during vascularization (HIF-1α) or catecholamine production (HLF). It is currently unknown how such specificity of action is achieved. We report here that DNA binding by HLF, but not by HIF-1α, is dependent upon reducing redox conditions. In vitro DNA binding and mammalian two-hybrid assays showed that a unique cysteine in the DNA-binding basic region of HLF is a target for the reducing activity of redox factor Ref-1. Although the N-terminal DNA-binding domain of HIF-1α can function in the absence of Ref-1, we found that the C-terminal region containing the transactivation domain requires Ref-1 for full activity. Our data reveal that the hypoxia-inducible factors are subject to complex redox control mechanisms that can target discrete regions of the proteins and are the first to establish a discriminating control mechanism for differential regulation of HIF-1α and HLF activity. Hypoxia-inducible factor 1α (HIF-1α) and the HIF-like factor (HLF) are two highly related basic Helix-Loop-Helix/Per-Arnt-Sim (bHLH/PAS) homology transcription factors that undergo dramatically increased function at low oxygen levels. Despite strong similarities in their activation mechanisms (e.g. they both undergo rapid hypoxia-induced protein stabilization, bind identical target DNA sequences, and induce synthetic reporter genes to similar degrees), they are both essential for embryo survival via distinct functions during vascularization (HIF-1α) or catecholamine production (HLF). It is currently unknown how such specificity of action is achieved. We report here that DNA binding by HLF, but not by HIF-1α, is dependent upon reducing redox conditions. In vitro DNA binding and mammalian two-hybrid assays showed that a unique cysteine in the DNA-binding basic region of HLF is a target for the reducing activity of redox factor Ref-1. Although the N-terminal DNA-binding domain of HIF-1α can function in the absence of Ref-1, we found that the C-terminal region containing the transactivation domain requires Ref-1 for full activity. Our data reveal that the hypoxia-inducible factors are subject to complex redox control mechanisms that can target discrete regions of the proteins and are the first to establish a discriminating control mechanism for differential regulation of HIF-1α and HLF activity. hypoxia-inducible factor 1α basic helix-loop-helix Per-Arnt-Sim HIF-like factor erythropoietin cAMP response element-binding protein nuclear factor κB glutathione S-transferase isopropyl-β-d-thiogalactopyranoside polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis dithiothreitol electrophoretic mobility shift assay xenobiotic response element hypoxia response element dioxin receptor glucocorticoid receptor Cells of aerobic organisms depend upon a plentiful supply of oxygen for energy production, and consequently, a number of mechanisms have evolved to sense and respond to disruptions of oxygen homeostasis. Although several signal transduction and gene regulatory mechanisms have been established to operate in response to oxidative stresses induced by intracellular oxygen radical production or cell penetration by oxidants, mammalian gene regulatory pathways that respond to hypoxia (low oxygen) have only recently begun to be understood. Analysis of hypoxia-induced activation of the erythropoietin gene led to the cloning of HIF-1α 1 (1.Wang G.L. Jiang B.H. Rue E.A. Semenza G.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 1230-1237Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1680) Google Scholar), a transcription factor that exhibits marked increases in stability and transcription potency at low intracellular oxygen levels (for a recent review, see Ref. 2.Semenza G.L. J. Lab. Clin. Med. 1998; 131: 207-214Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (185) Google Scholar). HIF-1α is a member of a bHLH protein subfamily that contains PAS dimerization domains juxtaposed with the bHLH. A number of bHLH/PAS factors have now been cloned and found to have crucial roles in physiological functions as diverse as xenobiotic metabolism (the dioxin or Ah receptor), maintenance of circadian rhythms (Clock and Period), and neurogenesis (Single-minded) (for a recent review, see Ref. 3.Crews S.T. Genes Dev. 1998; 12: 607-620Crossref PubMed Scopus (299) Google Scholar). Like the dioxin receptor, HIF-1α responds to environmental cues to form a functional heterodimer with a general bHLH/PAS partner protein, Arnt (Ah receptornuclear translocator). A closely related factor, the HIF-like factor (HLF (4.Ema M. Taya S. Yokotani N. Sogawa K. Matsuda Y. Fujii-Kuriyama Y. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. In vitro mechanistic analysis of HIF-1α and HLF revealed that they dimerize with Arnt with similar affinities (4.Ema M. Taya S. Yokotani N. Sogawa K. Matsuda Y. Fujii-Kuriyama Y. Proc. Natl. Acad. Despite strong sequence and mechanistic similarities and prevalent coexpression of HIF-1α and HLF, targeted disruption of their genes in mice results in embryonic lethalities with startling differences of phenotype. HIF-1α null mice (9.Iyer N.V. Kotch L.E. Agani F. Leung S.W. Laughner E. Wenger R.H. Gassmann M. Gearhart J.D. Lawler A.M., Yu, A.Y. Semenza G.L. Genes Dev. 1998; 12: 149-162Crossref PubMed Scopus (2008) Google Scholar, 10.Ryan H.E. Lo J. Johnson R.S. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 3005-3015Crossref PubMed Scopus (1318) Google Scholar) die at embryonic day 10 with defects in vascularization, whereas HLF null mice (11.Tian H. Hammer R.E. Matsumoto A.M. Russell D.W. McKnight S.L. Genes Dev. 1998; 12: 3320-3324Crossref PubMed Scopus (509) Google Scholar) die mid-gestation (days 12.5–16), suffering bradycardia and reduced catecholamine levels. These results establish that, at the very least, HIF-1α and HLF perform critically distinct functions during embryogenesis and indicate that they stimulate different target genes and/or undergo undiscovered differences in their in vivomechanisms of activation. To address the issue of how specificity of function between HIF-1α and HLF may be achieved, we have analyzed their DNA binding capacities under varying experimental conditions. The N-terminal DNA-binding basic regions of HIF-1α and HLF differ by a single amino acid, serine 28 in HIF-1α being replaced by cysteine 25 in HLF (see Fig. 3). Notably, single cysteines in the basic regions of Fos and Jun subunits of the AP-1 transcription factor complex render DNA binding subject to redox control. A protein with reducing activity, Ref-1 (redoxfactor 1), has been characterized as a factor that imparts strong DNA binding activity to the AP-1 complex by maintaining the cysteines as reduced sulfhydryl groups (12.Xanthoudakis S. Curran T. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 653-665Crossref PubMed Scopus (592) Google Scholar). Subsequently, a number of proteins containing cysteines in their DNA-binding domains have been found to have their DNA binding activities controlled by reducing factors such as Ref-1 (e.g. CREB, NF-κB, and Myb (12.Xanthoudakis S. Curran T. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 653-665Crossref PubMed Scopus (592) Google Scholar); p53 (13.Jayaraman L. Murthy K.G. Zhu C. Curran T. Xanthoudakis S. Prives C. Genes Dev. 1997; 11: 558-570Crossref PubMed Scopus (440) Google Scholar); and Pax5 and Pax8 (14.Tell G. Pellizzari L. Cimarosti D. Pucillo C. Damante G. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1998; 252: 178-183Crossref PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar, 15.Tell G. Scaloni A. Pellizzari L. Formisano S. Pucillo C. Damante G. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 25062-25072Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (97) Google Scholar)) or thioredoxin (e.g. the glucocorticoid receptor (16.Makino Y. Yoshikawa N. Okamoto K. Hirota K. Yodoi J. Makino I. Tanaka H. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 3182-3188Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (172) Google Scholar) and NF-κB (17.Hayashi T. Ueno Y. Okamoto T. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 11380-11388Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar)). We report here that Ref-1 imparts DNA binding to the cysteine-containing HLF bHLH/PAS A region, but does not influence the DNA binding activity of the serine-containing HIF-1α bHLH/PAS A region. Mammalian two-hybrid assays indicated that Ref-1 can interact with the HLF N-terminal sequence, but not the HIF-1α N terminus. As expected, expression of antisense Ref-1 RNA reduces the ability of HLF to function as a transcription factor, but surprisingly also compromises the transcription potency of HIF-1α. Through analysis of chimeric proteins, we have obtained evidence that Ref-1 is important for HIF-1α activity in a region C-terminal to the bHLH domain. Thus, the activities of both HIF-1α and HLF are under complex modes of redox control, with some distinction between domains subject to redox regulation, providing the first instance of differential control for activation of these two proteins. These results suggest a novel mechanism whereby specificity of hypoxia-induced gene regulation may be achieved. We have previously noted that the PAS A region of the dioxin receptor is important for the DNA binding activity of the DR/Arnt heterodimer (18.Pongratz I. Antonsson C. Whitelaw M.L. Poellinger L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 4079-4088Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar). As an extension of these studies, we sought to analyze the influence of the PAS A domain on the DNA binding activity of two other bHLH/PAS proteins, the closely related hypoxia-inducible factors HIF-1α and HLF. N-terminal regions of HIF-1α and HLF containing the bHLH domains, the PAS A domains, and the intervening amino acids between PAS A and PAS B (termed HIF-1α-(1–245) and HLF-(1–265) respectively) were expressed as GST fusion proteins in bacteria. A GST fusion protein of the full-length partner protein Arnt was also expressed in bacteria, and all proteins were purified to near homogeneity by glutathione-Sepharose affinity chromatography (Fig.1). Electrophoretic mobility shift assays have previously shown that in vitro translated HIF-1α and HLF, when combined with Arnt, recognize the same DNA sequences from hypoxia-responsive regions in the EPO and vascular endothelial growth factor genes (4.Ema M. Taya S. Yokotani N. Sogawa K. Matsuda Y. Fujii-Kuriyama Y. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 4273-4278Crossref PubMed Scopus (833) Google Scholar, 5.Tian H. McKnight S.L. Russell D.W. Genes Dev. 1997; 11: 72-82Crossref PubMed Scopus (1051) Google Scholar). As expected, when tested in isolation, bacterially expressed HIF-1α, HLF, and Arnt had no affinity for the hypoxia response element from the EPO gene (Fig.2, lanes 2–4). Surprisingly, however, we found that a mixture of purified HLF and Arnt showed barely detectable DNA binding activity on the EPO hypoxia response element (Fig. 2, lanes 5–7), whereas equivalent quantities of HIF-1α and Arnt exhibited clear DNA binding (lanes 8–10). This striking difference in activity was unexpected as sequence analysis of HLF and HIF-1α revealed a strong homology between the two DNA-binding and dimerization regions, with 83% identity between the bHLH domains and just under 70% identity over the PAS domains. This single amino acid difference is conserved for both human and mouse proteins. (Despite the original published sequence of HLF describing amino acid 25 as a serine, resequencing has confirmed a cysteine at this position, consistent with EPAS1 (5.Tian H. McKnight S.L. Russell D.W. Genes Dev. 1997; 11: 72-82Crossref PubMed Scopus (1051) Google Scholar), HIF-related factor (6.Flamme I. Frohlich T. von Reutern M. Kappel A. Damert A. Risau W. Mech. Chem. 1997; 272: 8581-8593Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (389) Google Scholar) sequences.) The position of this difference was intriguing, as cysteines in the DNA-binding basic regions of the oncoproteins Fos and Jun were found to mediate susceptibility for redox control of DNA binding activity (25.Abate C. Patel L. Rauscher III, F.J. Curran T. Science. 1990; 249: 1157-1161Crossref PubMed Scopus (1373) Google Scholar). Strikingly, these cysteines are in a highly similar immediate environment, flanked by basic amino acids (Fig. 3). In the case of Fos and Jun, mutation of the conserved cysteines to serines provided a higher affinity DNA-binding complex that was resistant to redox control and displayed increased cell transforming ability (26.Okuno H. Akahori A. Sato H. Xanthoudakis S. Curran T. Iba H. Oncogene. 1993; 8: 695-701PubMed Google Scholar). Xanthoudakis and Curran (12.Xanthoudakis S. Curran T. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 653-665Crossref PubMed Scopus (592) Google Scholar) isolated a protein from cell extracts (Ref-1) that was necessary for strong DNA binding activity of Fos and Jun. Ref-1 was found to be identical to the DNA repair enzyme APE/HAP-1 and to harbor two distinct activities, an N-terminal reducing function capable of interacting with cysteines and a C-terminal DNA repair function (20.Xanthoudakis S. Miao G.G. Curran T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 23-27Crossref PubMed Scopus (314) Google Scholar). To test whether the redox factor Ref-1 could influence DNA binding of HIF-1α and HLF, we expressed a histidine-tagged N-terminal redox domain of Ref-1 in bacteria and purified the protein by nickel affinity chromatography (Fig. 4 A). Upon addition of this purified Ref-(1–190) polypeptide to the EMSA reaction containing HLF and Arnt with the EPO hypoxia response element, a single DNA-binding entity was clearly observed (Fig. 4 B,lanes 7–9), whereas none was evident without Ref-(1–190) (lane 5), with the Ref-(1–190) polypeptide alone (lane 4), or with Ref-1 storage buffer (lane 10). Consistent with a model in which Ref-(1–190) supplies a reducing function critical for HLF DNA binding, the addition of dithiothreitol to the protein/DNA incubation also allowed conversion of the HLF/Arnt heterodimer to a DNA-binding form (Fig. 4 B,lane 6). In total contrast, the addition of either Ref-(1–190) or dithiothreitol to the HIF-1α/Arnt EMSA incubation did not influence the strength of DNA binding (Fig. 4 C, comparelanes 6 and 7–9 with lane 5). These results ascertain that a reducing activity needs to be present to invoke DNA binding of the HLF/Arnt heterodimer, but not the HIF-1α/Arnt heterodimer, and imply that a cysteine in the basic region of HLF may be a target of the Ref-1 reducing protein that also acts to provide strong DNA binding activity for the Fos-Jun complex. To determine whether the effect of Ref-1 was specific for HLF and was not a general effect on bHLH/PAS factors, an N-terminal region of the dioxin receptor encompassing the bHLH/PAS A domain was expressed as a GST fusion protein in bacteria and purified (Fig.5 A). When combined with bacterially expressed Arnt, a complex was formed that bound the XRE, the known target sequence of the DR/Arnt heterodimer (Fig.5 B). However, other cysteines in the HLF region being analyzed might also be affected by the redox conditions of the experiment. We therefore sought to obtain direct evidence that the basic region Cys25 is the target for redox control of HLF DNA binding. To this end, we created a point mutant in the HIF-1α-(1–245) N-terminal sequence that resulted in a switch from Ser28 to Cys28. This point mutant polypeptide was expressed as a GST fusion protein in bacteria and purified to provide HIF-1α-(1–245) S28C (Fig.6 A). When incubated with the radiolabeled probe from the EPO hypoxia response element, neither HIF-1α-(1–245) nor HIF-1α-(1–245) S28C alone showed any DNA binding activity (Fig. 6 B, lanes 3 and4). When combined with bacterially expressed and purified Arnt, HIF-1α-(1–245), but not HIF-1α-(1–245) S28C, exhibit

Sterol regulatory element-binding proteins (SREBPs) activate genes of cholesterol and fatty acid metabolism. In each case, a ubiquitous co-regulatory factor that binds to a neighboring recognition site is also required for efficient promoter activation. It is likely that gene- and pathway-specific regulation by the separate SREBP isoforms is dependent on subtle differences in how the individual proteins function with specific co-regulators to activate gene expression. In the studies reported here we extend these observations significantly by demonstrating that SREBPs are involved in both sterol regulation and carbohydrate activation of the FAS promoter. We also demonstrate that the previously implicated Sp1 site is largely dispensable for sterol regulation in established cultured cells, whereas a CCAAT-binding factor/nuclear factor Y is critically important. In contrast, carbohydrate activation of the FAS promoter in primary hepatocytes is dependent upon SREBP and both the Sp1 and CCAAT-binding factor/nuclear factor Y sites. Because 1c is the predominant SREBP isoform expressed in hepatocytes and 1a is more abundant in sterol depleted established cell lines, this suggests that the different SREBP isoforms utilize distinct co-regulatory factors to activate target gene expression. β-Amyloid protein is thought to underlie the neurodegeneration associated with Alzheimer's disease by inducing Ca2+-dependent apoptosis. Elevated neuronal expression of the proinflammatory cytokine interleukin-1β is an additional feature of neurodegeneration, and in this study we demonstrate that interleukin-1β modulates the effects of β-amyloid on Ca2+ homeostasis in the rat cortex. β-Amyloid-(1–40) (1 μm) caused a significant increase in45Ca2+ influx into rat cortical synaptosomes via activation of L- and N-type voltage-dependent Ca2+ channels and also increased the amplitude of N- and P-type Ca2+ channel currents recorded from cultured cortical neurons. In contrast, interleukin-1β (5 ng/ml) reduced the45Ca2+ influx into cortical synaptosomes and inhibited Ca2+ channel activity in cultured cortical neurons. Furthermore, the stimulatory effects of β-amyloid protein on Ca2+ influx were blocked following exposure to interleukin-1β, suggesting that interleukin-1β may govern neuronal responses to β-amyloid by regulating Ca2+homeostasis. β-Amyloid protein is thought to underlie the neurodegeneration associated with Alzheimer's disease by inducing Ca2+-dependent apoptosis. Elevated neuronal expression of the proinflammatory cytokine interleukin-1β is an additional feature of neurodegeneration, and in this study we demonstrate that interleukin-1β modulates the effects of β-amyloid on Ca2+ homeostasis in the rat cortex. β-Amyloid-(1–40) (1 μm) caused a significant increase in45Ca2+ influx into rat cortical synaptosomes via activation of L- and N-type voltage-dependent Ca2+ channels and also increased the amplitude of N- and P-type Ca2+ channel currents recorded from cultured cortical neurons. In contrast, interleukin-1β (5 ng/ml) reduced the45Ca2+ influx into cortical synaptosomes and inhibited Ca2+ channel activity in cultured cortical neurons. Furthermore, the stimulatory effects of β-amyloid protein on Ca2+ influx were blocked following exposure to interleukin-1β, suggesting that interleukin-1β may govern neuronal responses to β-amyloid by regulating Ca2+homeostasis. β-amyloid β-amyloid precursor protein Alzheimer's disease interleukin voltage-dependent Ca2+channel farad β-Amyloid (Aβ-(1–40))1is a peptide fragment derived from proteolytic processing of β-amyloid precursor protein (βAPP) (1.Selkoe D.J. Trends Neurosci. 1993; 16: 504-508Abstract Full Text PDF Scopus (433) Google Scholar), which accumulates as an insoluble extracellular deposit around neurons, giving rise to the senile plaques associated with Alzheimer's disease (AD) (2.Masters C.L. Simms G. Weinman N.A. Multhaup G. McDonald B.L. Beyreuther K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1985; 82: 4245-4249Crossref PubMed Scopus (3600) Google Scholar). Increased neuronal expression of the proinflammatory cytokine interleukin-1β (IL-1β) is an additional neuropathological hallmark of AD (3.Cacabelos R. Alvarez X.A. Fernandez-Nova L. Franco A. Mangues R. Pellicer A. Nishimura T. Methods Find. Exp. Clin. Pharmacol. 1994; 16: 141-151PubMed Google Scholar), and inflammatory mediators such as IL-1β have been proposed to contribute to the development of amyloid plaques (4.Sheng J.G. Mrak R.E. Griffin W.S. Neuropathol. Appl. Neurobiol. 1995; 21: 290-301Crossref PubMed Scopus (153) Google Scholar). Several reports describe an interaction between IL-1β and Aβ at the processing level; IL-1-immunoreactive microglia are prominent components of amyloid plaques in AD (4.Sheng J.G. Mrak R.E. Griffin W.S. Neuropathol. Appl. Neurobiol. 1995; 21: 290-301Crossref PubMed Scopus (153) Google Scholar), and β-amyloid promotes release of IL-1β by the glial cells that surround senile plaques (5.Araujo D.M. Cotman C.W. Brain Res. 1992; 569 (114): 140Crossref Scopus (282) Google Scholar). In turn, IL-1β increases βAPP mRNA expression (6.Patterson P.H. Curr. Opin. Neurobiol. 1995; 5: 642-646Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar) and promotes processing of βAPP to liberate Aβ peptide fragments (7.Vasilakos J.P. Carroll R.T. Emmerling M.R. Doyle P.D. Davis R.E. Kim K.S. Shivers B.D. FEBS Lett. 1994; 354: 289-292Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). Thus a chain of events involving IL-1β and Aβ is involved in plaque formation; however, the nature of the interaction between IL-1β and Aβ at a physiological level is poorly understood. Neuronal apoptosis is the suspected causative factor of neurodegeneration in AD, and Aβ fragments have been shown to promote apoptosis in vitro in human-derived neurotypic cells (8.Li Y.P. Bushnell A.F. Lee C.M. Perlmutter L.S. Wong S.K. Brain Res. 1996; 738: 196-220Crossref PubMed Scopus (153) Google Scholar) and cultured neurons (9.Loo D.T. Copani A. Pike C.J. Whittemore E.R. Walencewicz A.J. Cotman C.W. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 7951-7955Crossref PubMed Scopus (1040) Google Scholar). The mechanism underlying Aβ-induced apoptosis is thought to involve disregulation of Ca2+ homeostasis (10.Mattson M.P. Neurobiol. Aging. 1994; 15: 121-125Crossref PubMed Scopus (4) Google Scholar). In the C6 glial cell line, expression of the Ca2+-binding protein calbindin was found to suppress Aβ-induced apoptosis (11.Wernyj R.P. Mattson M.P. Christakos S. Mol. Brain Res. 1999; 64: 69-79Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar), providing evidence for the involvement of Ca2+ fluxes in Aβ-induced apoptosis. In this study we report that Aβ-(1–40) (i) promotes a stimulation of 45Ca2+ influx into cortical synaptosomes via activation of L- and N-type voltage-dependent Ca2+ channels (VDCCs) and (ii) increases the amplitude of N- and P-type VDCC current in cultured cortical neurons. Furthermore, the Aβ-(1–40)-induced increase in Ca2+ influx is blocked by the proinflammatory mediator IL-1β in both cortical synaptosome preparations and cultured cortical neuron preparations, providing evidence for a physiological interaction between IL-1β and Aβ-(1–40) with respect to the regulation of Ca2+ homeostasis.DISCUSSIONThe aim of this study was to examine the effects of Aβ-(1–40) and the proinflammatory cytokine IL-1β on Ca2+homeostasis in cortical synaptosomes and cultured cortical neurons. The results demonstrate that Aβ-(1–40) stimulates45Ca2+ influx into the synaptosomal preparation with a parallel rise in [Ca2+]i. The electrophysiological data demonstrate that Aβ-(1–40) also increases voltage-dependent Ca2+ channel activity in cultured cortical neurons. Since the stimulatory effects of Aβ-(1–40) on 45Ca2+ influx into cortical synaptosomes were blocked by nifedipine and ω-conotoxin GVIA we conclude that L- and N-type VDCCs are involved in the Aβ-induced elevation in 45Ca2+ influx in this preparation. In the cultured cortical neurons the Aβ-induced elevation in Ca2+ channel current neurons was found to be sensitive to ω-conotoxin GVIA and ω-agatoxin IVA, indicating the involvement of N- and P-type VDCCs. The data also demonstrate that the proinflammatory mediator IL-1β attenuates 45Ca2+ influx into cortical synaptosomes and reduces Ca2+ channel current density in cultured cortical neurons by approximately 50%, providing evidence that cortical voltage-sensitive Ca2+ channels are substrates for modulation by IL-1β. Furthermore, exposure to IL-1β was found to prevent the stimulatory effects of Aβ-(1–40) on Ca2+ influx, and this result is indicative of an interaction between Aβ-(1–40) and IL-1β with respect to the regulation of Ca2+ homeostasis.Our finding that Aβ-(1–40) stimulated 45Ca2+influx and elevated [Ca2+]i at the level of the nerve terminal means that Aβ-(1–40) is likely to have a significant impact on Ca2+-dependent neuronal functions such as neurotransmitter release and synaptic plasticity. In support of this hypothesis, β-amyloid peptides have been shown to potentiate Ca2+-dependent release of glutamate and aspartate from hippocampal slices (15.Arias C. Arrieta I. Tapia R. J. Neurosci. Res. 1995; 41: 561-566Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar), impair long term potentiation in the hippocampus (16.Cullen W.K. Suh Y.H. Anwyl R. Rowan M.J. Neuroreport. 1997; 8: 3213-3217Crossref PubMed Scopus (220) Google Scholar), and alter spatial memory performance tests (17.Sweeney W.A. Luedtke J. McDonald M.P. Overmier J.B. Neurobiol. Learn. Mem. 1997; 68: 97-101Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). Given that elevations in [Ca2+]i have been shown to precede apoptotic events in several cell systems (18.Trump B.F. Berezesky I.K. FASEB J. 1995; 9: 219-228Crossref PubMed Scopus (563) Google Scholar), the stimulation of 45Ca2+ influx and enhancement of VDCC activity by Aβ-(1–40) may act as a trigger for the neuronal apoptosis associated with neurodegenerative disease. In support of this suggestion, Aβ-induced increases in Ca2+ influx are reported to be involved in mediating the apoptotic effects of Aβ in PC12 cells (19.Fukuyama R. Wadhwani K.C. Galdzicki Z. Rapport S.I. Ehrenstein G. Brain Res. 1994; 667: 269-272Crossref PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar, 20.Yallampalli S. Micci M.A. Tagliatela G. Neurosci. Lett. 1998; 251: 105-108Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar), and L-type VDCCs have been demonstrated to mediate Aβ-induced neurotoxicity in cultured hippocampal neurons (21.Ueda K. Shinohara S. Yagami T. Asakura K. Kawaskai K. J. Neurochem. 1997; 68: 265-271Crossref PubMed Scopus (304) Google Scholar). In addition, mobilization of intracellular Ca2+ stores via formation of reactive oxygen species has been suggested to underlie the detrimental effects of Aβ-(25–35) on synaptosomal membrane lipid structure and composition (22.Koppal T. Subramaniam R. Drake J. Prasad M. Dhillon H. Butterfield D.A. Brain Res. 1998; 786: 270-273Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). Although elevation in [Ca2+]i has been demonstrated to underlie Aβ-induced neuronal apoptosis, Aβ also stimulates glia to produce growth factors that contribute to plaque development (5.Araujo D.M. Cotman C.W. Brain Res. 1992; 569 (114): 140Crossref Scopus (282) Google Scholar) and may influence neuronal viability (23.Bono F. Lamarche I. Bornia J. Savi P. Della Valle G. Herbert J.M. FEBS Lett. 1999; 457: 93-97Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). In addition, the ability of Aβ to induce expression of adhesion molecules (24.Suo Z. Tan J. Placzek A. Crawford F. Fang C. Mullan M. Brain Res. 1998; 807: 110-117Crossref PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar) may also play a significant role in the pathogenesis of AD.The subtype of VDCC modulated by Aβ-(1–40) in the cortical synaptosomes and cultured neurons was investigated using selective Ca2+ channel blockers. The L-type VDCC blocker nifedipine and the N-type VDCC inhibitor ω-conotoxin GVIA were both found to attenuate the K+-stimulated 45Ca2+influx in control cortical synaptosomes, indicating that L- and N-type VDCCs become activated following K+ depolarization. The finding that ω-conotoxin GVIA blocked K+-stimulated45Ca2+ influx in the synaptosomal preparation is consistent with a presynaptic role for the N-type VDCC because N-type VDCCs have been localized to nerve terminals, where they play a critical role in presynaptic events such as neurotransmitter release (25.Sabria J. Pastor C. Clos M.V. Garcia A. Badia A. J. Neurochem. 1995; 64: 2567-2571Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). In addition, a presynaptic role for L-type VDCCs has been described in cerebellar granule neurons (26.Huston E. Cullen G.P. Burley J.R. Dolphin A.C. Neuroscience. 1995; 68: 457-465Crossref Scopus (55) Google Scholar), and our finding that nifedipine attenuated the K+-induced increase in45Ca2+ influx in the synaptosomal preparation is consistent with previous studies that demonstrate the presence of L-type VDCCs in cortical synaptosomes (27.Boess F.G. Balasubramanian M.K. Brammer M.J. Campbell I.C. J. Neurochem. 1990; 55: 230-236Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar). The finding that nifedipine and ω-conotoxin GVIA also blocked the Aβ-mediated potentiation of the K+-induced increase in 45Ca2+influx in cortical synaptosomes suggests that N- and L-type VDCCs are targets for presynaptic modulation by Aβ-(1–40). In contrast, in the cultured cortical neurons a 20-ms, 110-mV depolarization from a holding potential of −90 mV resulted in activation of N- and P-type VDCCs, with little contribution from L-type VDCCs, demonstrating that N- and P-type VDCCs are prevalent in cultured cortical neurons. The Aβ-(1–40)-induced increase in Ca2+ channel current density was significantly reduced by ω-conotoxin GVIA and the P-type VDCC blocker ω-agatoxin IVA but was unaffected by the L-type VDCC blocker nimodipine, indicating that N- and P-type VDCCs are modulated by Aβ-(1–40) in these cells. In cerebellar granule neurons Aβ has been shown to act via exclusive up-regulation of N-type channels (28.Price S.A. Held B. Pearson H.A. Neurorepor t. 1998; 9: 539-545PubMed Google Scholar) and L-type VDCCs in microglia (29.Silei V. Fabrizi C. Venturini G. Salmona M. Bugiani O. Tagliavini F. Lauro G.M. Brain Res. 1999; 818: 168-170Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar); thus the nature of the VDCC regulated by Aβ may be dependent upon the cell type and subcellular fraction under investigation.We found that IL-1β attenuated 45Ca2+ influx in cortical synaptosomes in a similar manner to that previously reported in synaptosomes prepared from the hippocampus (30.Murray C.A. McGahon B. McBennett S. Lynch M.A. Neurobiol. Aging. 1997; 18: 343-348Crossref PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar). IL-1β functions as a neuromodulator to reduce neurotransmitter release (30.Murray C.A. McGahon B. McBennett S. Lynch M.A. Neurobiol. Aging. 1997; 18: 343-348Crossref PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar) and impair long term potentiation in the hippocampus (31.Cunningham A.J. Murray C.A. O'Neill L.A.J. Lynch M.A. O'Connor J.J. Neurosci. Lett. 1996; 203: 1-432Crossref PubMed Scopus (347) Google Scholar) possibly as a consequence of its inhibitory effect on Ca2+ influx (30.Murray C.A. McGahon B. McBennett S. Lynch M.A. Neurobiol. Aging. 1997; 18: 343-348Crossref PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar). The finding that IL-1β reduces Ca2+ channel current in cultured cortical neurons is also similar to the modulatory effects reported for IL-1β on hippocampal Ca2+ channel currents, where the IL-1β effects were found to proceed via activation of a pertussis toxin-sensitive G-protein (32.Plata-Salaman C.R. ffrench-Mullen J.M.H. Eur. J. Pharmacol. 1994; 266: 1-10Crossref PubMed Scopus (129) Google Scholar). Modulatory effects of IL-1β on Ca2+ homeostasis in cortical neurons and cortical nerve terminals are likely to have a significant impact on cortical function and may underlie the modulatory effects of IL-1β on synaptic transmission in the neocortex (33.D'Arcangelo G. Dodt H.U. Zieglansberger W. Neuroreport. 1997; 8: 2079-2083Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar).The finding that IL-1β blocked the stimulatory effects of Aβ-(1–40) on 45Ca2+ influx and Ca2+ channel currents is of particular interest. Elevations in neuronal expression of both Aβ (2.Masters C.L. Simms G. Weinman N.A. Multhaup G. McDonald B.L. Beyreuther K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1985; 82: 4245-4249Crossref PubMed Scopus (3600) Google Scholar) and IL-1β (3.Cacabelos R. Alvarez X.A. Fernandez-Nova L. Franco A. Mangues R. Pellicer A. Nishimura T. Methods Find. Exp. Clin. Pharmacol. 1994; 16: 141-151PubMed Google Scholar) are pathological features of Alzheimer's disease, and several lines of evidence demonstrate an interaction between Aβ and IL-β. β-Amyloid induces release of IL-1β from activated microglia (34.Lorton D. Kocsis J.M. King L. Maden K. Brunden K.R. J. Neuroimmunol. 1996; 67: 21-29Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and monocytes (35.Lorton D. Mech. Ageing Dev. 1997; 94: 199-211Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar) in a Ca2+-dependent manner and also promotes transcription of IL-1 mRNA (36.Hu J. Akama K.T. Krafft G.A. Chromy B.A. Van Eldik L.J. Brain Res. 1998; 785: 195-206Crossref PubMed Scopus (272) Google Scholar). Aside from the association of IL-1 with amyloid plaques (37.Griffin W.S.T. Stanley L.C. Ling C. White L. MacLeod V. Perrot L.J. White C.L. Araoz C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1989; 86: 7611-7615Crossref PubMed Scopus (1640) Google Scholar), where it is thought to contribute to gliosis, IL-1 is also believed to be influential at an earlier phase of AD pathology because this cytokine has been found to enhance βAPP mRNA expression in neurons (6.Patterson P.H. Curr. Opin. Neurobiol. 1995; 5: 642-646Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar) and promote processing of βAPP to generate β-amyloid fragments (7.Vasilakos J.P. Carroll R.T. Emmerling M.R. Doyle P.D. Davis R.E. Kim K.S. Shivers B.D. FEBS Lett. 1994; 354: 289-292Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). IL-1β and Aβ therefore participate in a cycle of events contributing to the formation of the neuritic plaques and tangles associated with AD. Although those studies reveal an interaction between Aβ and IL-1β at a processing level, little information is currently available concerning a physiological interaction between Aβ and IL-1β. The results presented in this study demonstrate that IL-1β modulates the Aβ-(1–40)-induced stimulation of Ca2+ influx in the cortex, and such neuromodulatory properties of IL-1β may participate in governing neuronal responses to Aβ at certain stages of the neurodegenerative disease process. Thus, whereas IL-1β is considered to have a significant influence on the pathophysiology of AD by increasing βAPP expression resulting in the formation of neuritic plaques (4.Sheng J.G. Mrak R.E. Griffin W.S. Neuropathol. Appl. Neurobiol. 1995; 21: 290-301Crossref PubMed Scopus (153) Google Scholar), the proclivity of IL-1β to attenuate Aβ-induced Ca2+ influxes at the level of the nerve terminal may impact on presynaptic function, such as the release of excitatory neurotransmitters, to limit cell damage caused by glutamate excitotoxicity, and as such this may reflect a neuroprotective role for IL-1β. Furthermore, because Aβ-induced neuronal apoptosis is dependent upon the activation of Ca2+-sensitive proteases (38.Jordan J. Galindo M.F. Miller R.J. J. Neurochem. 1997; 68: 1612-1621Crossref PubMed Scopus (170) Google Scholar) and Ca2+-sensitive tyrosine kinases (39.Combs C.K. Johnson D.E. Cannady S.B. Lehman T.M. Landreth G.E. J. Neurosci. 1999; 19: 928-939Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), our observation that IL-1β occludes the stimulatory effects of Aβ on Ca2+ influx suggests that IL-1β may serve to restrain these intracellular cascades associated with Aβ-induced neurodegeneration.In summary, the increase in Ca2+ influx mediated by Aβ-(1–40) in cortical synaptosomes and cultured cortical neurons is attenuated by the proinflammatory cytokine IL-1β. This finding indicates an interaction between Aβ and IL-1β that serves to regulate Ca2+ homeostasis, and this interaction may have implications in the manifestation of AD. β-Amyloid (Aβ-(1–40))1is a peptide fragment derived from proteolytic processing of β-amyloid precursor protein (βAPP) (1.Selkoe D.J. Trends Neurosci. 1993; 16: 504-508Abstract Full Text PDF Scopus (433) Google Scholar), which accumulates as an insoluble extracellular deposit around neurons, giving rise to the senile plaques associated with Alzheimer's disease (AD) (2.Masters C.L. Simms G. Weinman N.A. Multhaup G. McDonald B.L. Beyreuther K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1985; 82: 4245-4249Crossref PubMed Scopus (3600) Google Scholar). Increased neuronal expression of the proinflammatory cytokine interleukin-1β (IL-1β) is an additional neuropathological hallmark of AD (3.Cacabelos R. Alvarez X.A. Fernandez-Nova L. Franco A. Mangues R. Pellicer A. Nishimura T. Methods Find. Exp. Clin. Pharmacol. 1994; 16: 141-151PubMed Google Scholar), and inflammatory mediators such as IL-1β have been proposed to contribute to the development of amyloid plaques (4.Sheng J.G. Mrak R.E. Griffin W.S. Neuropathol. Appl. Neurobiol. 1995; 21: 290-301Crossref PubMed Scopus (153) Google Scholar). Several reports describe an interaction between IL-1β and Aβ at the processing level; IL-1-immunoreactive microglia are prominent components of amyloid plaques in AD (4.Sheng J.G. Mrak R.E. Griffin W.S. Neuropathol. Appl. Neurobiol. 1995; 21: 290-301Crossref PubMed Scopus (153) Google Scholar), and β-amyloid promotes release of IL-1β by the glial cells that surround senile plaques (5.Araujo D.M. Cotman C.W. Brain Res. 1992; 569 (114): 140Crossref Scopus (282) Google Scholar). In turn, IL-1β increases βAPP mRNA expression (6.Patterson P.H. Curr. Opin. Neurobiol. 1995; 5: 642-646Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar) and promotes processing of βAPP to liberate Aβ peptide fragments (7.Vasilakos J.P. Carroll R.T. Emmerling M.R. Doyle P.D. Davis R.E. Kim K.S. Shivers B.D. FEBS Lett. 1994; 354: 289-292Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). Thus a chain of events involving IL-1β and Aβ is involved in plaque formation; however, the nature of the interaction between IL-1β and Aβ at a physiological level is poorly understood. Neuronal apoptosis is the suspected causative factor of neurodegeneration in AD, and Aβ fragments have been shown to promote apoptosis in vitro in human-derived neurotypic cells (8.Li Y.P. Bushnell A.F. Lee C.M. Perlmutter L.S. Wong S.K. Brain Res. 1996; 738: 196-220Crossref PubMed Scopus (153) Google Scholar) and cultured neurons (9.Loo D.T. Copani A. Pike C.J. Whittemore E.R. Walencewicz A.J. Cotman C.W. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 7951-7955Crossref PubMed Scopus (1040) Google Scholar). The mechanism underlying Aβ-induced apoptosis is thought to involve disregulation of Ca2+ homeostasis (10.Mattson M.P. Neurobiol. Aging. 1994; 15: 121-125Crossref PubMed Scopus (4) Google Scholar). In the C6 glial cell line, expression of the Ca2+-binding protein calbindin was found to suppress Aβ-induced apoptosis (11.Wernyj R.P. Mattson M.P. Christakos S. Mol. Brain Res. 1999; 64: 69-79Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar), providing evidence for the involvement of Ca2+ fluxes in Aβ-induced apoptosis. In this study we report that Aβ-(1–40) (i) promotes a stimulation of 45Ca2+ influx into cortical synaptosomes via activation of L- and N-type voltage-dependent Ca2+ channels (VDCCs) and (ii) increases the amplitude of N- and P-type VDCC current in cultured cortical neurons. Furthermore, the Aβ-(1–40)-induced increase in Ca2+ influx is blocked by the proinflammatory mediator IL-1β in both cortical synaptosome preparations and cultured cortical neuron preparations, providing evidence for a physiological interaction between IL-1β and Aβ-(1–40) with respect to the regulation of Ca2+ homeostasis. DISCUSSIONThe aim of this study was to examine the effects of Aβ-(1–40) and the proinflammatory cytokine IL-1β on Ca2+homeostasis in cortical synaptosomes and cultured cortical neurons. The results demonstrate that Aβ-(1–40) stimulates45Ca2+ influx into the synaptosomal preparation with a parallel rise in [Ca2+]i. The electrophysiological data demonstrate that Aβ-(1–40) also increases voltage-dependent Ca2+ channel activity in cultured cortical neurons. Since the stimulatory effects of Aβ-(1–40) on 45Ca2+ influx into cortical synaptosomes were blocked by nifedipine and ω-conotoxin GVIA we conclude that L- and N-type VDCCs are involved in the Aβ-induced elevation in 45Ca2+ influx in this preparation. In the cultured cortical neurons the Aβ-induced elevation in Ca2+ channel current neurons was found to be sensitive to ω-conotoxin GVIA and ω-agatoxin IVA, indicating the involvement of N- and P-type VDCCs. The data also demonstrate that the proinflammatory mediator IL-1β attenuates 45Ca2+ influx into cortical synaptosomes and reduces Ca2+ channel current density in cultured cortical neurons by approximately 50%, providing evidence that cortical voltage-sensitive Ca2+ channels are substrates for modulation by IL-1β. Furthermore, exposure to IL-1β was found to prevent the stimulatory effects of Aβ-(1–40) on Ca2+ influx, and this result is indicative of an interaction between Aβ-(1–40) and IL-1β with respect to the regulation of Ca2+ homeostasis.Our finding that Aβ-(1–40) stimulated 45Ca2+influx and elevated [Ca2+]i at the level of the nerve terminal means that Aβ-(1–40) is likely to have a significant impact on Ca2+-dependent neuronal functions such as neurotransmitter release and synaptic plasticity. In support of this hypothesis, β-amyloid peptides have been shown to potentiate Ca2+-dependent release of glutamate and aspartate from hippocampal slices (15.Arias C. Arrieta I. Tapia R. J. Neurosci. Res. 1995; 41: 561-566Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar), impair long term potentiation in the hippocampus (16.Cullen W.K. Suh Y.H. Anwyl R. Rowan M.J. Neuroreport. 1997; 8: 3213-3217Crossref PubMed Scopus (220) Google Scholar), and alter spatial memory performance tests (17.Sweeney W.A. Luedtke J. McDonald M.P. Overmier J.B. Neurobiol. Learn. Mem. 1997; 68: 97-101Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). Given that elevations in [Ca2+]i have been shown to precede apoptotic events in several cell systems (18.Trump B.F. Berezesky I.K. FASEB J. 1995; 9: 219-228Crossref PubMed Scopus (563) Google Scholar), the stimulation of 45Ca2+ influx and enhancement of VDCC activity by Aβ-(1–40) may act as a trigger for the neuronal apoptosis associated with neurodegenerative disease. Shinohara S. Yagami T. Asakura K. Kawaskai K. J. Neurochem. 1997; 68: 265-271Crossref PubMed Scopus (304) Google Scholar).
