The 1-alkanol sensitivity of the NH2-terminal-deleted hKv3.4 (Δ1–28) was examined to rule out the influence of the inactivation domain on the inhibition by 1-alkanols. As expected, the deletion mutant exhibits no rapid inactivation, and as for the wild-type hKv3.4 and the SK chimera, the inhibition by 11 mm 1-butanol is also very small (4.8%; Fig. 3 A). In fact, the dose-inhibition curves from hKv3.4 and Δ1–28 were nearly identical (Fig. 3 B). Thus, the presence of the inactivation domain does not determine the low 1-alkanol sensitivity of hKv3.4. It is clear, however, that swapping the S4-S5 loop between hKv3.4 and dShaw2 is sufficient to enhance or reduce 1-alkanol action. Using site-directed mutagenesis, the S4-S5 loop of dShaw2 was progressively converted into that of hKv3.4 and vice versa to examine the contribution of added mutations to the inhibitory action of 1-alkanols (see TableI for nomenclature; Fig.4). Their effects were assessed by a protocol described above. In dShaw2 (Fig. 4 A), a minimum of six mutations was necessary to reduce the inhibitory effect of 1-butanol by 2-fold, and a complete conversion (seven substitutions) produced nearly an additional 2-fold reduction. Interestingly, the F322L and I319G/F322L mutations abolish functional expression, but when combined with other mutations they enhance inhibition by 1-alkanols (F322L/A326T and S3). This effect is reversed by two additional mutations K316R/I317V before a significant reduction of the 1-butanol sensitivity is apparent by the addition of a sixth mutation (K327N). In hKv3.4 (Fig. 4 B), a previously characterized single mutation (G371I) (6.Covarrubias M. Vyas T.B. Escobar L. Wei A. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 19408-19416Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar) was sufficient to enhance inhibition by ∼4-fold, and other double and triple mutations (L374F/T378A; G371I/T378A; and K3) also enhanced the inhibition considerably (∼3–5-fold). Notice, however, that two of these mutants already include the G371I mutation, and the mutation L374F in two mutants (G371I/L374F and K3) appears to partly reverse the level of inhibition established by G371I. As with F322L in dShaw2, the reverse mutation L374F at the equivalent site in hKv3.4 destroyed functional expression. Also, a hKv3.4 mutant with six substitutions exhibits enhanced inhibition above the level expected in wild-type dShaw2 channels (this mutant is characterized as the KS chimera in Fig. 3). Carboxypeptidase Z (CPZ) is a newly reported member of the metallocarboxypeptidase gene family, but unlike other members of this family, CPZ contains an N-terminal domain that has amino acid sequence similarity to Wnt-binding proteins. In order to gain insights as to the potential function of CPZ, the intracellular localization of this protein was determined in cell culture and in human tissues. When expressed in the AtT-20 mouse pituitary cell line, CPZ protein is routed to the regulated secretory pathway and secreted upon stimulation. A fraction of the secreted CPZ remains associated with the extracellular matrix. Endogenous CPZ in the PC12 rat pheochromocytoma cell line is also associated with the extracellular matrix. In human placenta, CPZ is present within invasive trophoblasts and in the surrounding extracellular space, indicating an association with extracellular matrix. CPZ is also present in amnion cells, but is not readily apparent in the extracellular matrix of this cell type. A human adenocarcinoma of the colon shows expression of CPZ in the extracellular matrix adjacent to malignant cells. Taken together, CPZ appears to be a component of the extracellular matrix in some cell types, where it may function in the binding of Wnt. Taken together, CPZ appears to be a component of the extracellular matrix in some cell types, where it may function in the binding of Wnt. carboxypeptidase Z carboxypeptidase E extracellular matrix Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium phosphate-buffered saline Metallocarboxypeptidases perform many functions, ranging from the digestion of food to the selective processing of neuroendocrine peptide hormones and neurotransmitters (1.$$$$$$ ref data missingGoogle Scholar). Altogether, there are 12 known members of the metallocarboxypeptidase gene family, which are further divided into two subgroups based on amino acid sequence similarities. Members of each subgroup share approximately 30–60% amino acid sequence identity with other members of the same group, but typically only 15–25% amino acid sequence identity with members of the other subgroup (1.$$$$$$ ref data missingGoogle Scholar). The two groups also differ in their general function; members of the carboxypeptidase A/B subgroup are typically digestive enzymes, while members of the subgroup containing carboxypeptidase E are referred to as “regulatory” enzymes (1.$$$$$$ ref data missingGoogle Scholar, 2.Skidgel R.A. Since CPZ does not resemble a transmembrane-spanning receptor, a more likely function would be analogous to that of frzb and other proteins that inactivate Wnt. To investigate whether CPZ is present in the parts of the cells where an interaction with Wnt is possible, we examined the intracellular distribution of endogenous CPZ in the PC12 cell line, a rat pheochromocytoma that expresses relatively high levels of CPZ, and in several human tissues. We also examined the distribution of exogenous CPZ in a cell line that does not normally produce detectable levels of CPZ. Our findings that CPZ is present in the secretory pathway and is associated with the extracellular matrix (ECM) are consistent with a role for CPZ as a Wnt-binding protein. CPZ was detected using rabbit polyclonal antisera raised against bacterially expressed glutathioneS-transferase fusion proteins. One fusion protein contained the C-terminal 73 amino acids of rat CPZ. AtT-20 cells were stably transfected with human CPZ under control of the cytomegalovirus promoter, and single colonies of stably transfected cells were identified by Western blot analysis, as described previously (14.Novikova E.G. Fricker L.D. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1999; 256: 564-568Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). Wild type and CPZ-expressing AtT-20 cells were cultured on growth-supporting glass coverslips (Fisher Scientific). PC12 cells were cultured on poly-d-lysine coverslips (Becton Dickinson). Cells were washed twice with DMEM, once with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), and then fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde for 10 min. The cells were rinsed in PBS, permeabilized in 0.1% Triton X-100 in PBS for 15 min, and then blocked in 5% bovine serum albumin for 1 h. After blocking, the cells were immunostained for 1 h with antisera raised against the CPZ C-terminal region (1:2000 dilution), and then washed three times for 5 min with 0.2% Tween 20 in PBS and once with PBS alone. To detect the antisera to CPZ, fluorescein-labeled goat anti-rabbit IgG (1:100 dilution) was added and the cells were incubated in the dark for 1 h. The cells were washed as described above, and the coverslips were mounted on the glass slides in 50% glycerol in PBS and examined using a Bio-Rad confocal microscope. AtT-20 cells (wild type and CPZ-expressing clones) were grown in 35-mm plates, washed twice with PBS, and once with serum-free DMEM. Cells were incubated at 37 °C in 500 μl of serum-free DMEM containing 0.2 μg/ml tetradecanoylphorbol 13-acetate, 10 μm forskolin, or control medium. After 30 min, the media were removed and collected on ice, and aliquots were tested for enzyme activity and analyzed by Western blotting (see below). AtT-20 and PC12 cells were grown in 60-mm dishes and were harvested when 90% confluent. After removal of the culture medium, cells were washed with PBS three times and then detached from the dishes with 1 mm EDTA in PBS. The dishes were then rinsed twice with EDTA. All washes were combined, and cells were collected after centrifugation at 500 × g for 15 min. The cell pellet was resuspended in 1 ml of sample buffer (50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.0, 1% SDS, 4% glycerol, 1% β-mercaptoethanol). The extracellular material remaining on the dishes after removal of the cells was extracted with 90 °C sample buffer (this fraction was designated ECM). Aliquots of the cell medium were also combined with sample buffer and heated to 90 °C for 5 min. Samples were fractionated on a denaturing 10% polyacrylamide gel and transferred to nitrocellulose. The blot was probed with 1:1000 dilution of antiserum, and the bound antiserum was detected with the enhanced chemiluminescence method (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). Cells cultured in 60-mm dishes (90% confluent) were incubated for 1 h in methionine-free DMEM. This medium was then removed and replaced with 1.5 ml of methionine-free DMEM containing 300 μCi/ml [35S]Met. The cells were labeled for 20 min (“pulse”), the radioactive medium was removed, and the cells were washed with PBS and incubated in DMEM (“chase”) for the indicated time. At each time point, the medium was collected, cells were washed with PBS, and lysed in 0.4 ml of 2% SDS in Buffer A (2.5% Triton X-100, 150 mm NaCl, 50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 100 μg/ml phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride). ECM fractions were extracted in 0.4 ml of the same buffer at 90 °C. Cells and ECM samples were sonicated, boiled for 10 min, diluted with 1.6 ml of Buffer A to reduce the SDS concentration to 0.4%, centrifuged at 12,000 ×g for 15 min, and the supernatant subjected to immunoprecipitation. Media samples were diluted 1:1 with 5% Triton X-100, 150 mm NaCl, 50 mm Tris-Cl, and 0.8% SDS. Cells, ECM, and media fractions were subjected to immunoprecipitation with 1:10 dilution of the antiserum directed against the N- or C-terminal regions of CPZ. For the analysis of the effect of glycosidases on the electrophoretic mobility of the CPZ, the labeling with [35S]Met was performed for 1 h. Following immunoprecipitation, the protein A-agarose pellets were boiled in 100 μl of denaturing buffer (New England Biolabs) for 10 min, and then 33-μl aliquots were mixed with endoglycosidase H or peptidyl-N-glycosidase F in G5 buffer (New England Biolabs), or with control buffer alone. The samples were incubated at 37 °C for 16 h and then fractionated on a denaturing polyacrylamide gel. Tissue sections taken from both the fetal and maternal sides of the central portion of placentae were retrieved from the human placental tissue bank, which stores liquid nitrogen snap-frozen placental tissues at −80 °C from over 2000 patients who delivered at Georgetown University Hospital. Tissue from five patients with normal spontaneous vaginal deliveries at 40 weeks' gestation, with no significant past medical or obstetrical history, were examined for CPZ immunoreactivity. Tissue sections of human adenocarcinoma were retrieved from the tumor bank, which stores liquid nitrogen snap-frozen cancer tissues at −80 °C from patients undergoing surgical resections of cancers at Jack D. Weiler Hospital. Studies involving human tissue were conducted with IRB approval (IRB protocol 1199707276.) Tissue blocks were warmed to −20 °C, mounted on a microtome chuck with optimal cutting compound, and sectioned at 4 μm. After air-drying for at least 1 h and desiccating for at least 24 h, sections were fixed in PBS containing 4% paraformaldehyde for 20 min. After extensive washing in PBS, sections were permeabilized with 0.2% Triton X-100 for 15 min. After subsequent washing in PBS, sections were incubated in a humidified chamber with 5% bovine serum albumin in PBS for 30 min to reduce nonspecific binding. Excess buffer was blotted off and the primary antiserum directed against the C-terminal region of CPZ, or preimmune serum for negative controls, was added, diluted 1:500 for placental staining and 1:200 for cancer tissue staining in PBS containing 1% bovine serum albumin and 0.1% Tween 20. For extracellular matrix marker studies, a monoclonal antibody directed against fibronectin (Sigma, clone FN-15) was used at the recommended dilution (1:10). After a 1-h incubation, the sections were washed in 0.2% Tween 20 in PBS. For the immunohistochemistry of human placental basal plate and adenocarcinoma, immunostaining was achieved using an avidin-biotin complex developer kit (Dako, Carpinteria, CA) and 3,3′-diaminobenzidine as substrate. Sections were counterstained with Mayer's hematoxylin. For immunofluorescence microscopy of human amnion, sections of fetal chorionic plate were incubated with anti-CPZ antiserum as described above and staining was developed with fluorescein-labeled anti-rabbit Ig antibody (Vector; Burlingame, CA) according to the manufacturer's instructions. Tissue sections were examined with a Bio-Rad confocal microscope. Wild type AtT-20 cells do not show detectable levels of CPZ mRNA (not shown) and show only background staining with an antiserum directed against the C-terminal region of CPZ (Fig.1). When four separate clonal lines of AtT-20 cells expressing high levels of CPZ were analyzed, only 20% of the cells in each line stained with the antiserum to CPZ (data not shown). Recloning the CPZ-expressing cells did not substantially change the fraction of cells that stained positively for CPZ protein. The CPZ staining is strongest in the tips of the cells, a result that resembles the localization of mature secretory vesicles (Fig. 1). In addition, punctate staining is seen throughout the cell body (Fig. 1). CPZ-expressing AtT-20 cells were examined by Western blot analysis. Cell extracts show two major bands of immunoreactive CPZ with apparent molecular masses of 68 and 72 kDa (Fig.2). Media from the CPZ-expressing AtT-20 cells showed only the smaller of these two forms (Fig. 2). The ECM fraction of the CPZ-expressing AtT-20 cells, defined as the material remaining on the cell culture plate following removal of the cells from the plate, contained the 72-kDa form of CPZ (Fig. 2). As a control, CPE was only detected in the cells and media, consistent with the localization of this protein to the regulated secretory pathway and not the ECM. The endoplasmic reticulum protein calnexin was detected only in the cellular fraction, further indicating that the ECM fraction is not contaminated by unremoved cells. In some experiments, the addition of heparin to the medium appeared to slightly decrease the amount of CPZ in the ECM fraction and increase the amount in the medium (Fig. 2). However, this effect was small and variable, with some experiments showing no effect of heparin on the distribution of CPZ (data not shown). Either forskolin or tetradecanoylphorbol 13-acetate stimulate the secretion of immunoreactive CPZ from the CPZ-expressing AtT-20 cells (Fig. 3 A). Quantitation of Western blots from six experiments shows approximately 3-fold stimulation of the secretion of immunoreactive CPZ (Fig.3 B). Duplicate Western blot analysis with an antiserum to CPE showed an increase upon treatment with secretagogue (Fig.3 A), consistent with previous reports (24.Mains R.E. Eipper B.A. Endocrinology. 1984; 115: 1683-1690Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar, 25.Klein R.S. Das B. Fricker L.D. J. Neurochem. 1992; 58: 2011-2018Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar). Enzymatic assays of the media with dansyl-Phe-Ala-Arg at pH 7.4 showed 5–10-fold more activity in medium from the CPZ-expressing AtT-20 cells than medium from wild type cells (Fig. 3 C). As found using Western blot analysis, treatment with secretagogues increased the levels of enzymatic activity at neutral pH from four different CPZ-expressing AtT-20 cell lines (Fig. 3 C). In contrast, the medium from wild type AtT-20 cells had very low levels of carboxypeptidase activity, which did not increase upon secretagogue treatment (Fig. 3 C); these assay conditions are not expected to detect CPE, which is maximally active at pH 5.5 and virtually inactive at neutral pH (26.Greene D. Das B. Fricker L.D. Biochem. J. 1992; 285: 613-618Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar). Pulse/chase analysis with [35S]Met was used to follow the biosynthesis of CPZ in the CPZ-expressing AtT-20 cells. Following a 20-min incubation with [35S]Met, a strong band of 72 kDa is detected upon immunoprecipitation with a CPZ-directed antiserum (Fig. 4 A). After a 30-min chase in unlabeled Met, the CPZ appeared as a slightly broader band in the cell extracts, and as a very faint signal in the ECM fraction (Fig.4 A). Following 3 or 6 h of chase, less of the CPZ was associated with the cell fraction and more was detected in the ECM and media fractions. The cellular form after 3 or 6 h of chase existed as 72- and 68-kDa forms, whereas the ECM form was predominantly 72 kDa and the media predominantly 68 kDa (Fig. 4 A). Treatment of the immunoprecipitate with glycosidases reduced the size of the cellular 72-kDa form of CPZ to 66 kDa (Fig. 4 B). After 0 or 0.5 h of chase, the cellular 72-kDa form was largely endoglycosidase H-sensitive, whereas after 3 h of chase a portion of the CPZ was endoglycosidase H-resistant (Fig. 4 B). The forms of CPZ in the ECM and media were also endoglycosidase H-resistant following 3 h of chase. The 68-kDa band seen in cells and media following 3 h of chase is reduced to 64 kDa upon removal of all N-linked sugars by peptidyl-N-glycosidase F. Of the various cell lines previously examined, PC12 cells showed the highest expression of CPZ mRNA (13.Xin X. Day R. Dong W. Lei Y. Fricker L.D. DNA Cell Biol. 1998; 17: 311-319Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). Within wild type PC12 cells, CPZ immunoreactivity is diffuse with accumulation near the cell surface in a subset of the cells (Fig. 5). The staining near the cell surface is consistent with the typical staining of secretory granules in the PC12 cell line (27.Kromer A. Glombik M.M. Huttner W.B. Gerdes H. J. Cell Biol. 1998; 140: 1331-1346Crossref PubMed Scopus (91) Google Scholar). In addition to the punctate staining near the cell surface, staining is also detected at the junctions of some cells (Fig. 5). As with the transfected AtT-20 cells, the endogenous CPZ in PC12 cells is detected in only a subset of cells, representing approximately 20% of the cells. The majority of the PC12 cells show only a diffuse background staining that is similar to the level of staining observed with preimmune antiserum. To test whether CPZ is also present in the ECM fraction of PC12 cells, Western blot analysis was performed. As found for AtT-20 cells expressing CPZ, the endogenous CPZ is detected in the ECM fraction from PC12 cells (Fig. 6). The apparent molecular mass of the ECM CPZ (72 kDa) is similar to the size of the cellular CPZ. In contrast, immunoreactive CPZ in the PC12 medium is 53 kDa (Fig. 6). Since the antiserum used to detect the medium CPZ was raised against the C-terminal region, this media form presumably represents an N-terminally truncated form. Relatively large amounts of the 53-kDa form of CPZ were consistently observed in multiple experiments with PC12 medium. (In comparing Figs. 2 and 6, note the different amounts of each fraction analyzed on the Western blot; see figure legend.) The distribution of CPZ was examined in human tissues. Of the various human tissues previously examined by Northern blot analysis, placenta showed the highest expression of CPZ mRNA (6.Song L. Fricker L.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 10543-10550Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar). Two placental cell types show CPZ immunoreactivity (Fig. 7). In the maternal basal plate, nearly all of the invasive trophoblasts identified show intense CPZ immunostaining, with a subset of basal plate trophoblasts showing immunostaining in the ECM around the periphery of the cells (Fig. 7 A). In the fetal chorionic plate, the amnionic epithelial cells consistently show CPZ immunoreactivity. Although no definite staining is seen in the amnionic ECM, the CPZ immunostaining in the amnion cells is polarized, with CPZ staining on the apical side of the cells, which is normally adjacent to amnionic fluid (Fig. 7 C). The distribution of CPZ was also examined in a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon. Scattered foci of CPZ immunoreactivity were seen throughout the tissue sections (Fig. 7 E). In stained areas, CPZ immunoreactivity is present in the ECM surrounding and coursing between a subpopulation of malignant cells. A similar pattern of immunostaining was observed when parallel sections were reacted with a monoclonal antibody directed against fibronectin, an ECM marker (Fig. 7 G). Co-localization studies, using fluorescein-labeled anti-rabbit Ig secondary antibodies and rhodamine-labeled anti-mouse Ig secondary antibodies, show nearly complete overlap of CPZ and fibronectin immunoreactivity in some areas of human colon cancer tissue sections (data not shown). One major finding of the present study is that, when CPZ is expressed in AtT-20 cells, it is routed to the regulated secretory pathway. Regulated secretion of CPZ suggests that this enzyme either plays a role in the regulated pathway (as with CPE), or else functions after secretion (as with neuropeptides). Of these two possibilities, the latter is more consistent with the non-neuroendocrine distribution of CPZ (6.Song L. Fricker L.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 10543-10550Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar, 13.Xin X. Day R. Dong W. Lei Y. Fricker L.D. DNA Cell Biol. 1998; 17: 311-319Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar) and with the enzyme properties (14.Novikova E.G. Fricker L.D. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1999; 256: 564-568Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). Based on the neutral pH optimum of CPZ, and its relative inactivity at the acidic pH of the secretory vesicles, it is most likely that CPZ functions outside the cell. Additionally, many cells that express CPZ (leptomeningeal cells, amnion cells, trophoblasts) are not known to contain a regulated secretory pathway and in these cell types CPZ would presumably be secreted via the constitutive pathway. The finding that a subpopulation of the PC12 cells expressed CPZ protein was unexpected. A similar result was found when CPZ was expressed in AtT-20 cells and clonal cell lines isolated. It is unlikely that this is due to a mixed population of cells, since a second round of cloning did not alter the fraction of cells expressing CPZ. It is possible that levels of CPZ are regulated by the cell cycle. Since the cytomegalovirus promoter was used for the stable expression of CPZ in AtT-20 cells, and not the endogenous promoter, it is unlikely that the variation in levels among cells is due to transcriptional control. Instead, regulation at the levels of translation, stability, or cellular binding are more likely to account for the variable levels of CPZ in the different cells. Similar to the results with cultured cells, CPZ immunoreactivity was detected at the junctions between a subpopulation of the cells in a human carcinoma. However, in the placenta the majority of invasive trophoblasts and amnion cells expressed CPZ. Thus, some but not all systems show large variability in levels of CPZ within a homogeneous population of cells. Another major finding of the present study is that CPZ is associated with the ECM. Previously, CPZ was found to bind heparin, as do other components of the ECM. However, heparin alone does not substantially alter the relative ratio of CPZ in the media and ECM of cells, suggesting that binding of CPZ to the ECM involves multiple domains. The observation that the media form of CPZ is approximately 4 kDa smaller than the ECM form in CPZ-expressing AtT-20 cells suggests that the ECM binding domain is within this 4-kDa region. Since the 4-kDa difference is not due to N-linked carbohydrates, the likely explanation is proteolysis at the N and/or C termini. A comparison of rat and human CPZ shows a highly conserved C-terminal 35 amino acids (6.Song L. Fricker L.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 10543-10550Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar, 13.Xin X. Day R. Dong W. Lei Y. Fricker L.D. DNA Cell Biol. 1998; 17: 311-319Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). The degree of amino acid identity over the C-terminal 35 residues (78%) is considerably higher than an adjacent region (36%) or the N-terminal 30 residues following removal of the signal sequence (25%). The degree of sequence identity within the C-terminal region is comparable to the sequence identity within the Cys-rich domain that is predicted to bind Wnts (77%), suggesting a function for the C-terminal region. It is possible that the C-terminal region functions in the binding of CPZ to the ECM. There are 8 basic residues and no acidic residues within the C-terminal 32 residues, and these are conserved in human and rat (6.Song L. Fricker L.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 10543-10550Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar, 13.Xin X. Day R. Dong W. Lei Y. Fricker L.D. DNA Cell Biol. 1998; 17: 311-319Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). A consensus site for furin and related prohormone convertases (RARR-Q, with cleavage predicted to occur between the R and Q) is located 29 residues from the C terminus. Cleavage by furin would shorten the CPZ by 3.6 kDa, consistent with the observed size shift. Although furin is primarily located in the trans-Golgi network, this endopeptidase also cycles to the cell surface and has been shown to function in the cleavage of several proteins in the extracellular environment (28.Nakayama K. Biochem. J. 1997; 327: 625-635Crossref PubMed Scopus (699) Google Scholar, 29.Molloy S.S. Anderson E.D. Jean F. Thomas G. Trends Cell Biol. 1999; 9: 28-35Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (313) Google Scholar). Thus, cleavage of CPZ by furin could occur either during transport to the cell surface, or following expression on the cell surface. Alternatively, prohormone convertase 1 could cleave the RARR site within CPZ; this endopeptidase is enriched in the regulated secretory pathway in AtT-20 cells (30.Hornby P.J. Rosenthal S.D. Mathis J.P. Vindrola O. Lindberg I. Neuroendocrinology. 1993; 58: 555-563Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). Although the size of CPZ in the cells and ECM fractions of the PC12 cell line is similar to the size in the corresponding fractions of the CPZ-expressing AtT-20 cells, the form of CPZ in the medium of the PC12 cells is much smaller. It is not clear if this form is produced within the cells or after secretion. Based on the size of the form secreted from PC12 cells and on the binding of the antisera directed against the C-terminal region, this form presumably lacks the N-terminal cysteine-rich domain. Further studies to identify the cleavage site are difficult due to the low levels of secreted protein. Although CPZ has been previously purified from CPZ-expressing AtT-20 cells (14.Novikova E.G. Fricker L.D. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1999; 256: 564-568Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar), the amount of protein was undetectable on polyacrylamide gels and so it is not possible to perform N-terminal sequence analysis. The finding that CPZ is present in the ECM raises a number of possible functions for this enzyme. It is possible that the cysteine-rich domain of CPZ interacts with Wnts, based on homology between CPZ and other Wnt-binding proteins such as the frizzled receptors and the frizzled-related proteins. Since CPZ is not a transmembrane spanning protein, it would more likely function as a frizzled-related protein rather than a receptor. The carboxypeptidase domain of CPZ may also be involved with Wnt proteins; many of these proteins are predicted to contain a C-terminal lysine or arginine based on their nucleotide sequences. It is not known whether the forms of the Wnt proteins that exist in the ECM contain these C-terminal basic residues, or whether removal of this basic group would alter their function. It is also possible that the carboxypeptidase domain of CPZ is important for other pathways. There are a number of endopeptidases that cleave extracellular matrix and which are involved in tissue remodeling during development (31.Werb Z. Chin J.R. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1998; 857: 110-118Crossref PubMed Scopus (174) Google Scholar, 32.Westermarck J. Kahari V.M. FASEB J. 1999; 13: 781-792Crossref PubMed Scopus (1385) Google Scholar). CPZ may play a role in the cleavage of extracellular matrix following the action of an endopeptidase. This is supported by the localization of CPZ to the invasive trophoblasts in the placenta (Fig. 7). However, the limited distribution and narrow substrate specificity of CPZ (13.Xin X. Day R. Dong W. Lei Y. Fricker L.D. DNA Cell Biol. 1998; 17: 311-319Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar, 14.Novikova E.G. Fricker L.D. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1999; 256: 564-568Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar) would argue against a general degradative role for this enzyme. Further studies are needed to establish the precise function of CPZ within the ECM. Confocal microscopy was performed in the Analytical Imaging Facility of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine.

Pepocin, isolated from Cucurbita pepo, is a ribosome-inactivating protein (RIP). RIPs site-specifically recognize and depurinate an adenosine at position 4324 in rat 28 S rRNA, rendering the ribosome incapable of interacting with essential elongation factors. Aptamers that target pepocin were isolated from a degenerate RNA pool by in vitro selection. A conserved hairpin motif, quite different from the sequence of the toxin-substrate domain in rat 28 S rRNA, was identified in the aptamer sequences. The aptamers selectively bind to pepocin with dissociation constants between 20 and 30 nm and inhibit theN-glycosidase activity of pepocin on rat liver 28 S rRNA. Competitive binding experiments using aptamer variants suggest that the conserved hairpin region in the anti-pepocin aptamer binds near the catalytic site on pepocin and prevents the interaction of pepocin and 28 S rRNA. Anti-RIP aptamers have potential use in diagnostic systems for the detection of pepocin or could be used as therapy to prevent the action of pepocin in mammalian cells. Pepocin, isolated from Cucurbita pepo, is a ribosome-inactivating protein (RIP). RIPs site-specifically recognize and depurinate an adenosine at position 4324 in rat 28 S rRNA, rendering the ribosome incapable of interacting with essential elongation factors. Aptamers that target pepocin were isolated from a degenerate RNA pool by in vitro selection. A conserved hairpin motif, quite different from the sequence of the toxin-substrate domain in rat 28 S rRNA, was identified in the aptamer sequences. The aptamers selectively bind to pepocin with dissociation constants between 20 and 30 nm and inhibit theN-glycosidase activity of pepocin on rat liver 28 S rRNA. Competitive binding experiments using aptamer variants suggest that the conserved hairpin region in the anti-pepocin aptamer binds near the catalytic site on pepocin and prevents the interaction of pepocin and 28 S rRNA. Anti-RIP aptamers have potential use in diagnostic systems for the detection of pepocin or could be used as therapy to prevent the action of pepocin in mammalian cells. ribosome-inactivating protein(s) Ribosome-inactivating proteins (RIPs)1 are widely distributed throughout nature (for review, see Ref. 1.Barbieri L. Battelli M.G. Stirpe F. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1154: 237-282Crossref PubMed Scopus (848) Google Scholar). They inhibit protein synthesis in mammalian cells by disabling the ribosome. Type II RIPs (e.g. ricin) are heterodimeric proteins; an A-chain catalyzes the depurination of a specific adenosine in rRNA, and a disulfide linked B-chain binds cell surface galactosides (for review, see Ref. 2.Wool I.G. Glück A. Endo Y. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1992; 17: 266-269Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (190) Google Scholar). Binding of the B-chain to the cell surface results in translocation of the A-chain to the cytosol, where it hydrolyzes theN-glycosidic bond of a universally conserved adenosine in the large subunit of rRNA. Cleavage of the adenine residue disrupts the binding of elongation factors, inactivating the ribosome. Type I RIPs, of which pepocin is a member, are considerably more numerous in nature but much less cytotoxic because they lack the B-chain required for cell entry (3.Endo Y. Tsurugi K. Ebert R.F. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1988; 954: 224-226Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). The depurination site in the large subunit of rRNA is highly conserved in many eukaryotes and is located in a hairpin loop of 17-mer containing a GAGA tetraloop, in which the second A is removed (4.Endo Y. Tsurugi K. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 8735-8739Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 5.Endo Y. Tsurugi K. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 8128-8130Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Recent studies using RNA variants of the toxin-substrate domain have shown that small hairpin fragments containing a GAGA tetraloop are also able to act as substrates for ricin (6.Glück A. Endo Y. Wool I.G. J. Mol. Biol. 1992; 226: 411-424Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar). The cleavage reaction is remarkably specific, and the GAGA sequence is essential for toxin recognition. For instance, the A-chain of ricin does not recognize hairpin variants with all of the possible transitions and transversions of each nucleotide in the GAGA tetraloop sequence (6.Glück A. Endo Y. Wool I.G. J. Mol. Biol. 1992; 226: 411-424Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar). NMR studies indicate that RNA fragments corresponding to the toxin-substrate domain of rRNAs form the GAGA tetraloop hairpin (7.Orita M. Nishikawa F. Shimayama T. Taira K. Endo Y. Nishikawa S. Nucleic Acids Res. 1993; 21: 5670-5678Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar, 8.Szewczak A.A. Moore P.B. Chan Y. Wool I.G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 9581-9585Crossref PubMed Scopus (228) Google Scholar, 9.Szewczak A.A. Moore P.B. J. Mol. Biol. 1995; 247: 81-98Crossref PubMed Scopus (187) Google Scholar, 10.Orita M. Nishikawa F. Kohno T. Senda T. Mitsui Y. Endo Y. Taira K. Nishikawa S. Nucleic Acids Res. 1996; 24: 611-618Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar). The structure of the GAGA tetraloop is similar to those of stable GAAA and GCAA (GNRA) loops, whereas these are not recognized by the toxins (6.Glück A. Endo Y. Wool I.G. J. Mol. Biol. 1992; 226: 411-424Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar). These results illustrate the importance of both sequence and structure for recognition in RNA-protein complexes; studies of the contacts between RNA hairpins and RIPs are informative as a model system for scrutinizing RNA-protein interactions. In vitro selection can be used to generate nucleic acid ligands (aptamers) that bind to target proteins and thus can answer questions regarding which components of an RNA molecule are essential for binding to its target protein (11.Baskerville S. Frank D. Ellington A.D. Simons R. Grunberg-Manago M. RNA Structure and Function. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1998: 203-251Google Scholar, 12.Gold L. Polisky B. Uhlenbeck O. Yarus M. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1995; 64: 763-797Crossref PubMed Scopus (753) Google Scholar, 13.Bartel D.P. Szostak J.W. Nagai K. Mattaj I. RNA-Protein Interaction. Oxford University Press, Oxford1995: 248-268Google Scholar). For instance, crystal structures of RNA aptamers that bind MS2 coat protein shed light on the nature of specific interactions between coat protein and operator (14.Convery M.A. Rowsell S. Stonehouse N.J. Ellington A.D. Hirao I. Murray J.B. Peabody D.S. Phillips S.E.V. Stockley P. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1998; 5: 133-139Crossref PubMed Scopus (120) Google Scholar,15.Rowsell S. Stonehouse N.J. Convery M.A. Adams C.J. Ellington A.D. Hirao I. Murray J.B. Peabody D.S. Stockley P. Phillips S.E.V. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1998; 5: 970-975Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar). Despite the structural differences between the aptamers and the wild type operator, the aptamers bind in the same location on the coat protein as the wild type RNA and maintain many of the same contacts with the protein compared with the wild type RNA. In a similar example, RNA aptamers that bind elongation factor Tu (EF-Tu) were isolated byin vitro selection (16.Hornung V. Hofmann H. Sprinzl M. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 7260-7267Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar). EF-Tu is known to interact with an RIP recognition domain in rRNA. A consensus sequence identified within the aptamers was found in the toxin-substrate domain of Thermus thermophilus 23 S rRNA. To identify novel anti-RIP compounds, we used in vitroselection to produce RNA ligands that bind the toxin, pepocin, which is a type I RIP isolated from the sarcocarp of Cuburbita pepo(17.Yoshinari S. Yokota S. Sawamoto H. Koresawa S. Tamura M. Endo Y. Eur. J. Biochem. 1996; 242: 585-591Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). Because the single A-chain of pepocin containsN-glycosidic cleavage activity against the large subunit of rRNA but is not highly toxic, it was considered to be a suitable model system for the study of RIP recognition and inhibition. Pepocin and gypsophilin were isolated from the sarcocarp of C. pepo. (17.Yoshinari S. Yokota S. Sawamoto H. Koresawa S. Tamura M. Endo Y. Eur. J. Biochem. 1996; 242: 585-591Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar) and from Gypsophila elegans (18.Yoshinari S. Koresawa S. Yokota S. Sawamoto H. Tamura M. Endo Y. Biosci. Biotech. Biochem. 1997; 61: 324-331Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar), respectively. The purity of proteins was checked by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis with silver staining. Oligodeoxyribonucleotides were synthesized using standard phosphoramidite chemistry on a DNA synthesizer (392, Perkin-Elmer). [α-32P]UTP and [γ-32P]ATP were purchased from Amersham Pharmacia Biotech (Uppsala, Sweden). RNase T1 and RNase V1 were purchased from Amersham Pharmacia Biotech, nuclease S1 was from Takara (Tokyo, Japan), and RNase I was from Promega (Madison, WI). In vitro selection was carried out using an RNA pool that contained 30 randomized nucleotide positions (19.Conrad R.C. Brück F.M. Bell S. Ellington A.D. Nucleic Acid-Protein Interactions: A Practical Approach. Oxford University Press, London1995: 285-315Google Scholar). The RNA pool was transcribed from the DNA template using an Ampliscribe T7 in vitro transcription kit (Epicenter Technologies, Madison, WI). RNA was dissolved in 10 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.6), 50 mm NaCl, and 10 mm MgCl2 and then heated at 75 °C for 3 min and cooled to room temperature. To exclude filter-binding RNA sequences from the pool, the RNA was passed over a 0.45-μm HAWP filter (Millipore, Bedford, MA) two or three times before incubation with target. The RNA was mixed with a pepocin preparation (10 mmsodium phosphate (pH 6.5), 100 mm NaCl, 0.5 mmdithiothreitol, and 40% glycerol). The final solution contained 3 mm sodium phosphate, 3 mm MgCl2, 45 mm NaCl, 2.5 mm EDTA, 3 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.5), 0.15 mm dithiothreitol, and 12% glycerol. TableI summarizes the conditions used in each round of the selection. The binding was carried out for 1 h at 37 °C. After 1 h, the solution was vacuum filtered over a HAWP filter at 5 p.s.i. and washed five times with 0.2 ml of the selection buffer. The RNA on the filter was eluted twice with 0.2 ml of 7 m urea, 100 mm sodium citrate (pH 5.0), and 3 mm EDTA for 5 min at 100 °C, and the eluted RNAs were precipitated with isopropyl alcohol. In the fifth through eighth rounds, an additional filtration step was carried out on the eluted RNA pool to further exclude filter-binding species (20.Hirao, I., Peabody, D. S., and Ellington, A. D. (1999) Mol. Diversity, in pressGoogle Scholar). Collected RNA was reverse transcribed in 50 mm Tris-HCl (pH 8.0), 40 mm KCl, 6 mm MgCl2, 0.8 mm dNTPs, 4 μm primer, and 2.5 units of avian myeloblastosis virus reverse transcriptase (Seikagaku, St. Petersburg, FL) for 45 min at 42 °C. The reverse transcription was then added to a polymerase chain reaction amplification mix containing 50 mm KCl, 10 mm Tris-HCl (pH 8.3), 1.5 mm MgCl2, 0.2 mm dNTPs, 5% acetamide, 0.05% Nonidet-P-40, 0.5 μm primers, and 0.5 unit of Taq polymerase (Promega) and thermally cycled. Plasmid DNAs were isolated and sequenced using an AutoRead sequencing kit and a DNA sequencer (ALF, Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). The RNA pools from each round and individual clones from the eighth round were internally labeled with [α-32P]UTP (3000 Ci/mmol) during T7 transcription. The labeled RNA (0.3 μm final concentration) was mixed with pepocin (0.3 μm final concentration) in 0.1 ml of the selection buffer for 1 h at 37 °C. The solution was then filtered and washed three times with selection buffer. The filter was exposed to a PhosphorImager plate, and the amount of retained radioactivity was determined using a PhosphorImager (Fuji Photo Film, Kanagawa, Japan). The mixture was filtered on a vacuum manifold (Schleicher & Schuell) loaded with a piece of pure nitrocelluolse membrane (0.45 μm, Bio-Rad) over a piece of Zeta-Probe blotting membrane (Bio-Rad) (19.Conrad R.C. Brück F.M. Bell S. Ellington A.D. Nucleic Acid-Protein Interactions: A Practical Approach. Oxford University Press, London1995: 285-315Google Scholar, 21.Weeks K.M. Cech T.R. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 7728-7738Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). The radioactivity on both filters was quantified, and dissociation constants (K d) were determined by curve fitting with the program Kaleidagraph (Abelbeck Software, Reading, PA). The binding activity of each aptamer variant was determined by competition experiments between a 5′-labeled aptamer variant and 5′-labeled clone 8-09. Both RNAs (each at 0.45 μm final concentration) were mixed with pepocin (0.3 μm final concentration) in 100 μl of the selection buffer for 1 h at 37 °C. The mixture was passed over a HAWP filter and washed three times with 0.2 ml of the selection buffer. The RNAs on the filter were eluted with 0.1 ml of 0.025% of bromphenol blue, 7 m urea, 100 mm sodium citrate (pH 5.0), and 3 mm EDTA for 5 min at 100 °C. The solution was applied directly to a gel containing 7 m urea. The radioactivity in each band on the gel was quantified using a PhosphorImager. Binding ratios were calculated by comparing the counts in the retained and input RNA. For Tm measurements, each aptamer (0.7 A 260 final concentration) was dissolved in 0.25 ml of a buffer containing 10 mm sodium phosphate (pH 7.0), 1 m NaCl, and 1 mm EDTA. Before measurement, the aptamer solution was heated at 75 °C for 3 min and then cooled to room temperature. Melting profiles were obtained at 260 nm using a spectrophotometer (DU650, Beckman) at a heating rate of 0.5 °C/min with 1-cm cuvettes.Tm values were calculated from the first derivatives of the melting curves. The end-labeled 9-41 and 9-41U20 (3 pmol) were used for digestion experiments. Alkaline digestion was performed in 50 mm sodium carbonate (pH 9.0), 1 mm EDTA, and 5 ng of E. coli tRNAs for 10 min at 90 °C. RNase T1 digestion (0.01 unit) was performed in 20 mm sodium citrate (pH 5.0), 7 m urea, 1 mm EDTA, 0.025% bromphenol blue, and 5 ng of E. coli tRNAs for 5 min at 50 °C. RNase V1 digestion (0.05 and 0.1 unit) was performed in 50 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.5), 10 mm MgCl2, and 5 ng of E. coli tRNAs for 10 min at 37 °C. S1 nuclease digestion (1 unit) was performed in 30 mm sodium acetate (pH 4.6), 280 mm NaCl, 10 mm ZnSO4, and 5 ng of E. coli tRNAs for 30 min at 37 °C. RNase I digestion (0.3 unit) was performed in 10 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.5), 5 mm EDTA, 200 mm sodium acetate, and 5 ng of E. coli tRNAs for 10 min at 37 °C. The digested samples were analyzed on a 15% polyacrylamide gel with 7 m urea at 50 °C. Pepocin (308 pm final concentration) was incubated with increasing concentrations of anti-pepocin aptamers (0.308–7.7 μm) in 25 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.6), 25 mm KCl, and 5 mm MgCl2 for 15 min at 37 °C. Into the premixed solution, rat liver ribosome (180 nm final concentration) was added and incubated for 15 min at 37 °C. The RIP reaction was stopped with 10% SDS (0.5% final concentration) and 1m KCl (0.1 m final concentration). After phenol extraction, rRNA was precipitated and dissolved in 5 μl of water. Subsequently, 25 μl of a solution of acetic acid and aniline was added to the rRNA, and the cleavage reaction was incubated for 15 min at 37 °C. Cleavage reactions were run on a 4% polyacrylamide gel containing 7 m urea, and RNAs were detected by staining with ethidium bromide. We carried out selection experiments using an RNA pool that contained a region of 30 randomized nucleotides flanked by constant regions. The relatively short length of the randomized region was chosen because several plant toxins recognize and hydrolyze a specific adenine in small synthetic hairpin fragments (4.Endo Y. Tsurugi K. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 8735-8739Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 22.Endo Y. Glück A. Wool I.G. J. Mol. Biol. 1991; 221: 193-207Crossref PubMed Scopus (126) Google Scholar). In addition, RNA pools containing relatively short randomized regions have frequently proven sufficient to identify aptamers that bind tightly to a target protein. For example, the same 21-residue motif was found in anti-tyrosine phosphatase aptamers isolated from two pools that contained random regions that were either 30 or 71 nucleotides in length (23.Bell S.D. Denu J.M. Dixon J.E. Ellington A.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 14309-14314Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar). Selection experiments were initiated with an RNA pool containing 2 × 1013 different sequences. Table I shows the conditions used throughout the selection. After eight rounds of selection, the fraction of the pool which bound pepocin had increased from 0.03 to 24%. Although some filter-binding species accumulated during the middle rounds of the selection, postfiltration of selected RNAs successfully removed the filter-binding species. Twenty-six clones were isolated from the eighth round of selection (Fig. 1). Twenty-three of these aptamers had a similar sequence and bound specifically to pepocin. Aptamers that were closer to a consensus sequence tended to exhibit higher binding activity, and the proportion of a variant in the selected population correlated well with its affinity for pepocin (Figs.2 and 3). The other three RNAs, 8-24, 8-25, and 8-26, do not exhibit specific binding to pepocin; 8-24 has no affinity for the protein, and 8-25 and 8-26 bind to the filter rather than the protein.Figure 2Conserved hairpin structure between two classes of anti-pepocin aptamers. The stem 1 regions of the class 1 aptamers are depicted as the part of the loop structure. The G-U base pair in stem 2 is underlined. Numbers inparentheses indicate the results of the pepocin filter binding assay described under “Experimental Procedures.” Aptamers are sorted according to their affinities for pepocin fromleft to right.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)Figure 3Competition experiments using small RNA fragments derived from clone 8-09 or 28 S rRNA. The indicated32P-labeled RNA fragments were incubated with pepocin and32P-labeled clone 8-18, and complexes were captured by filtration and subsequently analyzed by electrophoresis on a denaturing polyacrylamide gel. Lane a contains RNAs present at the start of the binding reaction, and lane b contains RNAs recovered after filtration. The binding ratios are indicated inparentheses and were calculated as described under “Experimental Procedures.”View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) Sequence variations observed among the 23 similar clones are consistent with the formation of a stem-loop structure. For example, although 7 ligands have a CAG/CUG sequence in stem 2, 12 ligands change this stem sequence to GGA/UUC, 2 ligands to AGG/CUU, and one ligand to AAG/CUU. Therefore, most ligands have an NUAU loop and two bulged cytidines, one between stems 1L and 2L, and one between stems 2L and 3L (Fig. 2). Interestingly, the sequence of the anti-pepocin aptamer hairpin motif is quite different from the toxin-substrate domain GAGA in rRNAs. Based on sequence differences in stem 1L, the anti-pepocin aptamers can be classified into two groups, class 1 and class 2. Class 1 ligands have a UAG or a UCG sequence and a mismatched base pair in stem 1L. In contrast, class 2 ligands have a UUG sequence in this region and form an uninterrupted stem 1 structure. Thus, class 1 aptamers may form a similar but slightly different hairpin structure than class 2 aptamers. Fig. 2 summarizes the structural variations in each class and the results of binding assays with pepocin. It was observed that a G-U base pair in stem 2 of both class 1 and class 2 aptamers produced better binding than canonical base pairs. The fact that class 1 and class 2 aptamers, and individual aptamers within class 1 and class 2, were likely derived from different initial molecules further emphasizes the importance of the non-canonical loop structure for pepocin binding. To determine the minimal sequence necessary for anti-pepocin aptamer binding, we prepared various mutant fragments of the class 1 aptamer 8-09, which bound the best in our initial assays. To quantify the binding abilities of each fragment better, competition experiments were carried out. Selected small RNA fragments were competed with 8-18, an aptamer that bound specifically but poorly to pepocin. A 45-mer fragment of aptamer 8-09 (termed 9-45), which contained the AUAU loop, stems 1–4, and the two bulged cytidines competed roughly twice as well with 8-18 for binding to pepocin (Fig. 3 a). The binding activity of aptamer 9-45 was improved slightly by introducing substitutions (UAA to AAG) that closed the apparent internal loop of aptamer 8-09, generating aptamer 9-45b. The fully paired stem was observed in many other class 1 aptamers such as 8-08 and 8-01. A 41-mer fragment, 9-41, had binding activity similar to that of 9-45b, but binding activity decreased after additional truncation (9-37 (37-mer) and 9-33 (33-mer)) (Fig.3 b). These results are consistent with the predicted secondary structure, which shows 10 base pairs between stems 3 and 4. Most of the aptamers isolated from the eighth round pool were also predicted to contain approximately 10 base pairs in stems 3 and 4. It should be noted that all of the aptamers bound much better to pepocin than the isolated toxin-substrate domain of rRNA; for example, aptamer 9-45b binds roughly 100-fold better than the isolated toxin-substrate domain. There is some sequence degeneracy at specific positions in the loop and stem regions of the aptamers. Four different bases appeared at the first position of the loop, although the UAU motif was highly conserved at the remaining three positions in the loop. We examined the binding abilities of these variants by introducing substitutions into the minimal aptamer 9-41. The binding activities of these variants are shown in Fig. 4. As has been observed in other selection experiments (11.Baskerville S. Frank D. Ellington A.D. Simons R. Grunberg-Manago M. RNA Structure and Function. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1998: 203-251Google Scholar), sequence variations between the aptamers provided valuable information about the function. The order of the binding activity of the class 1 loop sequence variants was UUAU > CUAU > AUAU > GUAU. Similarly, 6ix of 13 class 1 NUAU loops are UUAU, 3 are CUAU, 4 are AUAU, and no GUAU loops appear. The tightest binding aptamer was the class 1 aptamer (9-41U22) containing a UUAU sequence in the loop. The K d of 9-41U22 was 17.9 ± 2.2 nm, which was similar to that of the full-length aptamers 8-09 (21.0 ± 2.0 nm) and 8-14 (23.4 ± 2.3 nm) (Fig.5 a).Figure 5Binding curves for anti-pepocin aptamers with pepocin or gypsophilin. Different concentrations of protein were mixed with a fixed concentration (0.6 nm) of aptamer at 37 °C for 1 h, and the percent binding was determined using a filter binding assay. a, binding curves for aptamers with pepocin. The calculated dissociation constants for aptamers 8-14, 8-09, and 9-41U22 were 23 ± 2, 21 ± 2, and 18 ± 2 nm, respectively. b, binding curves for aptamer 8-09 with pepocin or gypsophilin. The pepocin binding curve is the same as in a.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) Changes outside the loop region also affected activity. The second base pair in stem 1L was predicted to be A-A or C-A in class 1 aptamers but U-A in class 2 aptamers. The substitution of the class 1 C-A base pair to a class 2 U-A (9-41U20) decreased binding activity slightly. Interestingly, the class 1 aptamer, 9-41 (Tm = 82.5 °C) was found to be more thermally stable than the class 2 aptamer, 9-41U20 (Tm = 80.0 °C). Finally, both bulged cytidines located in the stem region appear to be important for binding. Substitution of the bulged C to either U or A reduced the binding activity significantly. Overall, it appeared that the sequences in and around stems 1 and 2 contributed to interactions with pepocin. Although all sequence and binding data were consistent with the predicted secondary structures, we enzymatically probed the structures of both class 1 (9-41) and class 2 (9-41U20) aptamers. Labeled 9-41 and 9-41U20 were treated with RNase V1, S1 nuclease, and RNase I (Fig.6). RNase V1 digests double-stranded regions in the RNA specifically. S1 nuclease and small amounts of RNase I preferentially digest single-stranded regions in RNAs. Both 9-41 and 9-41U20 gave similar digestion patterns, with the exception of RNase V1 digestion in the stem 1 region (positions 18–20 and 26–28 in Fig. 6) and RNase I digestion throughout stem 1 and the loop regions (position 17–27). The digestion pattern of 9-41U20 was consistent with the predicted tetra loop (the NUAU loop) hairpin structure. However, 9-41 may have a structure different from that of 9-41U20 at positions 18–28, including the loop and stems 1 and 2. RNase V1 digestion of 9-41 did not give strong bands at position 18–20 in the stem 1L region compared with 9-41U20. In contrast, RNase I extensively digested 9-41 throughout the loop and the stem 1 regions, although S1 nuclease treatment gave similar digestion patterns for 9-41 and 9-41U20. Under the conditions that we used, the RNase I activity was expected to be slightly stronger than nuclease S1 activity. Therefore, although enzymatic probing confirms that class 1 and class 2 aptamers form secondary structures similar to those predicted, the class 1 aptamers seem to have more flexible stem 1 and loop regions. To determine whether the anti-pepocin aptamers could inhibit ribosome inactivation by pepocin, we examined the depurination of the specific adenosine in rat liver 28 S rRNA. Rat liver ribosomes and pepocin were incubated together in the presence of increasing concentrations of aptamers. The 28 S rRNA was extracted from the ribosome and treated with aniline to cleave the rRNA at the depurination site. The aniline-treated rRNA was analyzed on a denaturing gel (Fig. 7), and the expected cleavage product of 28 S rRNA was observed (Fig. 7, lane 2). The addition of a class 1 aptamer, 8-09, in 10,000-fold excess over pepocin inhibited the depurination of 28 S rRNA (Fig. 7 a,lane 9). The inhibitory effect of a class 2 aptamer, 8-14, was weaker than that of class 1 and was observed at around a 25,000-fold excess (Fig. 7 a, lane 6). Although the small fragments 9-41U22 and 9-41U20U22 bound tightly to pepocin, they showed no inhibitory effect when present in ten-thousand fold excess (Fig. 7 b). The simplest explanation of anti-pepocin aptamer inhibition of rRNA depurination is that the aptamer competes with rRNA for binding to pepocin. However, to account for the large excess of aptamer needed for inhibition, we considered the possibility that the aptamer might also be a substrate for pepocin. To determine if pepocin depurinated one or more positions in the aptamers, resulting in a loss of activity, the aptamers were incubated with pepocin for 1 day at 37 °C followed by treatment with aniline. No depurination or cleavage products were observed (data not shown). Because the sequence of the toxin-substrate domain in 28 S rRNA is highly conserved in many eukaryotes, if the anti-pepocin aptamers mimicked the rRNA domain then it seemed possible that the anti-pepocin aptamers might bind and inhibit other RIPs. We examined the ability of these aptamers to bind to and inhibit another RIP, gypsophilin, isolated from G. elegans (18.Yoshinari S. Koresawa S. Yokota S. Sawamoto H. Tamura M. Endo Y. Biosci. Biotech. Biochem. 1997; 61: 324-331Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). Aptamers 8-09, 8-14, and 9-41U20 did not bind to gypsophilin (Fig. 5 b), and gypsophilin activity was not inhibited by the addition of the aptamers in up to a 25,000-fold excess over protein (data not shown). Thus, anti-pepocin aptamers are remarkably selective for pepocin. Thus, although the anti-pepocin aptamers compete with rRNA for binding to pepocin, they do not appear to do so by mimicking universal features of rRNAs. In concert with our other results, two additional features of the mechanism of binding and inhibition are suggested. First, the fact that the class 1 aptamers form a semistable stem-loop structure that nonetheless binds tightly and specifically to pepocin suggests that the conformation of the aptamers may change on binding pepocin. This hypothesis is also consistent with the observed specificity of the aptamers for pepocin. Second, it is possible that the anti-pepocin aptamers bind adjacent to but do not necessarily fill the pepocin active site. This assumption is supported by the fact that the full-length class 1 aptamer, 8-09, inhibits pepocin activity, whereas the small fragment, 9-41U22, of the class 1 aptamer is not effective even though its K dis smaller than that of 8-09. Partial occlusion of a protein active site by an aptamer has been observed previously for protein tyrosine phosphatases (23.Bell S.D. Denu J.M. Dixon J.E. Ellington A.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 14309-14314Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar). Along these lines, it is also possible that two RNA recognition sites exist in pepocin; one site could bind efficiently to a portion of a RNA substrate, and the other is the catalytic site that hydrolyzes the adenine residue in rRNA. This interpretation is consistent with the fact that small synthetic RNA hairpins bind poorly and are not hydrolyzed by pepocin. This model would be similar to the two-site recognition known to occur with other ribosome-associating proteins such as elongation factors EF-G and EF-Tu (24.Moazed D. Robertson J.M. Noller H.F. Nature. 1988; 344: 362-364Crossref Scopus (417) Google Scholar). EF-Tu and EF-G interact with both the thiostrepton binding site in the 1067 region and the toxin recognition site in the 2660 region of 23 S rRNA. From this vantage, the selected aptamers might block the hypothesized substrate binding site but not necessarily the catalytic site. The identification of anti-RIP aptamers may suggest new approaches to the development of therapeutics or diagnostics for toxic agents. To the extent that the anti-pepocin aptamer has been shown to inhibit RIP activity, it provides proof of principle for the development of prophylactic or therapeutic aptamers to other cytotoxins, such as the Vero toxin produced by E. coli O157 (25.Karmali M.A. Petric M. Lim C. Fleming P.C. Arbus G.S. Lior H. J. Infect. Dis. 1985; 151: 775-781Crossref PubMed Scopus (1111) Google Scholar, 26.Milford D.V. Taylor C.M. Gutteridge B. Hall S.M. Rowe B. Kleanthous H. Arch. Dis. Child. 1990; 65: 716-721Crossref PubMed Scopus (162) Google Scholar, 27.Inward C.D. Williams J.M. Chant I.D. Crocker J. Milford D.V. Rose P.E. Taylor C.M. J. Infect. 1995; 30: 213-218Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar). Such aptamers could be introduced as expression constructs into exposed or at-risk individuals to minimize toxin pathology. Moreover, anti-toxin diagnostics using aptamers might be powerful tools for detecting trace amounts of toxins. For example, anti-pepocin aptamers might be used in biosensors that would detect the presence of pepocin in foods made from pumpkin.

Dynactin is a multisubunit complex and a required cofactor for most, or all, of the cellular processes powered by the microtubule-based motor cytoplasmic dynein. Using a dynein affinity column, the previously uncharacterized p62 subunit of dynactin was isolated and microsequenced. Two peptide sequences were used to clone human cDNAs encoding p62. Sequence analysis of the predicted human polypeptide of 53 kDa revealed a highly conserved pattern of eleven cysteine residues, eight of which fit the consensus sequence for a Zn2+-binding RING domain. We have characterized p62 as an integral component of 20 S dynactin by biochemical and immunocytochemical methods. Affinity chromatography experiments demonstrate that p62 binds directly to the Arp1 subunit of dynactin. Immunocytochemistry with antibodies to p62 demonstrates that this polypeptide has a punctate cytoplasmic distribution as well as centrosomal distribution typical of dynactin. In transfected cells, overexpression of p62 did not disrupt microtubule organization or the integrity of the Golgi but did cause both cytosolic and nuclear distribution of the protein, suggesting that this polypeptide may be targeted to the nucleus at very high expression levels.
